LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Republic of Indonesia 
   
Classification  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
Sector: Law, economic management, and public policy 
Subsector: National government administration 
Themes: Governance, sustainable economic growth, capacity 
development 
Subthemes: Financial and economic governance, promoting 
macroeconomic stability, institutional development 
 
Environment Assessment  Category C 
   
Program Description  The fourth Development Policy Support Program (DPSP-4) is 
the fourth such operation in Indonesia. It is in substantive terms 
a continuation of DPSPs 1–3, the programmatic series of annual 
single-tranche  operations  from  2005  to  2007.  The  DPSP 
series—cofinancing the Development Policy Loan (DPL) series 
supported by the World Bank and the Government of Japan—is 
embedded  in  the  Government’s  Medium-Term  National 
Development  Plan  (RPJM)  for  2004–2009.  It  supports  the 
RPJM’s  broad  goals  of  stimulating  higher  and  sustainable 
economic  growth  with  lower  levels  of  unemployment  and 
poverty, in three core areas: (i) investment climate, (ii) enhanced 
public  financial  management  and  governance,  and  (iii)  public 
service delivery to the poor. The DPSP-4 is also proposed as a 
single-tranche  operation  based  on  completed  actions 
demonstrating  satisfactory  progress.  It  builds  on  reforms 
undertaken during past DPSPs and sets the groundwork for an 
expanded policy dialogue for future operations. 
   
Rationale  In addition to the economic rationale mentioned above, the DPL 
series  aims  to  harmonize  policy  reform  support  from  key 
development  partners.  The  involvement  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) in the DPL process effectively builds 
on  and  deepens  sector-specific  reforms  supported  by  ADB 
through  its  past,  ongoing,  and  planned  operations  under  the 
Indonesia country strategy and program 2006–2009. 
 
ADB’s participation in the DPL also stems from its endeavors to 
reduce transaction costs for its developing member countries. 
The  approach  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  reform  agenda,  as 
outlined in the long-term strategic framework and the middle-
income  country  initiative.  Participation  in  the  DPL  helps 
implement and fulfill ADB’s obligations to the Rome Declaration 
on Harmonization (February 2003) and the Paris Declaration on 
Aid Effectiveness (March 2005).

ii   
Impact and Outcome  The impact of the DPSP-4 will be in the form of higher economic 
growth that is sustained over the medium term, and lower levels 
of poverty and unemployment. Its principal outcome is improved 
overall economic management anchored on good governance 
through (i) an investment climate, (ii) improved public financial 
management and good governance, and (iii) improved delivery 
of public services.  
   
Financing Plan  For the DPSP-4, the Government has requested ADB to provide 
a loan of $200 million. The DPSP-4 provides parallel cofinancing 
for the World Bank-supported fifth DPL (DPL-5), for which the 
Government has requested $750 million. The Government also 
intends to request parallel cofinancing of $100 million from the 
Government of Japan for the DPL-5. 
   
Loan Amount and Terms  A  single-tranche  program  loan  of  $200  million  from  ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources will be provided under ADB’s London 
interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility. The loan 
will have a 15-year term, including a grace period of 3 years; an 
interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s LIBOR-based 
lending  facility;  a  commitment  charge  of  0.15%  per  annum; 
conversion options that may be exercised in accordance with the 
draft  Loan  Agreement,  the  loan  regulations,  and  ADB’s 
conversion guidelines; and such other terms and conditions as 
are set forth in the draft Loan Agreement. 
   
Disbursement  The loan will be disbursed in a single tranche upon declaration of 
loan effectiveness. 
   
Program Period  The  program  implementation  period  for  the  DPSP-4  is  from 
January  to  December  2008  and  the  loan  amount  will  be 
disbursed  in  a  single  tranche  upon  declaration  of  loan 
effectiveness. All actions included in the policy matrix have been 
implemented within the year. The DPSP-4 fits within the overall 
reform agenda supported under the DPLs, which cover 2003–
2008. 
   
Executing Agency  Coordinating Ministry of Economic Affairs 
   
Procurement  The  loan  proceeds  will  be  used  to  finance  the  full  foreign 
exchange  costs  (excluding  local  duties  and  taxes)  of  items 
produced  and  procured  in  ADB  member  countries,  excluding 
ineligible  items  and  imports  financed  by  other  bilateral  and 
multilateral sources. In accordance with the provisions of ADB’s 
Simplification  of  Disbursement  Procedures  and  Related 
Requirements for Program Loans (1998), the loan proceeds will 
be disbursed to the Republic of Indonesia as the Borrower. No 
supporting import documentation will be required if, during each 
year  when  loan  proceeds  are  expected  to  be  disbursed,  the 
value  of  Indonesia’s  total  imports  minus  imports  from 
nonmember countries, ineligible imports, and imports financed

iii
under other official development assistance is equal to or greater 
than the amount of the loan expected to be disbursed during 
such year. The Government will certify its compliance with this 
formula  with  each  withdrawal  request.  Otherwise,  import 
documentation under existing procedures will be required. ADB 
reserves the right to audit the use of loan proceeds and verify 
the accuracy of the Government’s certification. 
   
Program Benefits and  The key benefits expected from the DPSP series are (i) progress 
Beneficiaries  toward  the  Government’s  medium-term  objectives  of 
macroeconomic  stability  and  creditworthiness,  improved 
investment  climate,  reduced  corruption,  and  improved 
governance; (ii) raising the profile of key issues at the ministerial 
level, accelerating the timetable for policy actions to be taken, 
addressing  administrative  and  bureaucratic  bottlenecks,  and 
providing an impetus for decision makers to coordinate further 
across  economic  and  line  ministries;  (iii)  institutional 
development  within  government  institutions,  Bank  Indonesia, 
and banks; (iv) greater public confidence in the banking system 
stemming from implementation of the deposit protection scheme; 
(v)  sustained  ADB  engagement  in  policy  dialogue  with  the 
Government on the direction and content of, and strategies for, 
its economic, structural, and institutional reform agenda—with 
the DPSP-4 providing for policy continuity and consistency in 
sectors where ADB has been actively involved; (vi) facilitation, 
through crosscutting reforms, of sector-specific reforms in areas 
where  ADB  is  providing  or  planning  support;  and 
(vii) harmonization and parallel financing by the key development 
partners (ADB, World Bank, and Government of Japan) around a 
common  policy  framework  and  dialogue,  and  the  resulting 
endorsement of the Government’s sound policy implementation 
and macroeconomic management. 
 
Risks and Safeguards  Implementation of the DPSP series is subject to the following 
risks:  
(i)  External  vulnerabilities.  With  improvements  in  its 
macroeconomic  indicators,  Indonesia’s  resilience  to 
external  shocks  has  increased.  Factors  limiting  the 
potential impacts of external shocks include diversity of 
exports, limited external debt exposure, and an adequate 
level  of  reserves.  The  banking  sector  is  also  now 
sufficiently strong to weather a moderate external shock. 
The  maintenance  of  a  financial  sector  safety  net 
supported  by  the  DPL/DPSP  will  help  to  improve  the 
resilience  of  the  banking  sector.  However,  significant 
subsidies  continue  in  fuel  and  electricity,  despite  the 
Government’s decision to raise fuel prices by 28.7% in 
May 2008. There is a risk of an adverse market reaction 
to growing expenditures on energy subsidies. Indonesia 
has considerable gross financing needs and the cost of 
meeting these will almost certainly go up if outlays on oil

iv   
subsidies and budgetary financing needs continue to go 
up.  In  such  an  environment,  a  sharp  deterioration  in 
global  economic  conditions  could  make  Indonesia 
particularly  vulnerable  to  sudden  shifts  in  investor 
sentiment, possibly triggering rapid capital outflows and 
raising the risks of broader financial sector disruption.  
(ii)  Fiduciary  constraints.  Notwithstanding  the 
improvements under way, there are continuing concerns 
regarding  utilization  of  public  resources.  The  overall 
fiduciary assessments undertaken since 2001 (with the 
country  financial  accountability  assessment)  have 
indicated  considerable  improvements  in  the  overall 
fiduciary  environment  in  Indonesia.  Ongoing  programs 
supported  by  several  development  partners  provide 
significant  technical  assistance  support  to  strengthen 
fiduciary governance. The DPL/DPSP focus on improving 
budget  preparation,  execution,  and  transparency  in 
financial  management  will  significantly  enhance 
transparency.  
(iii) The  2009  legislative  and  presidential  elections. 
Although  the  Government  remains  committed  to 
sustaining its economic reform agenda despite the global 
economic  slowdown  and  general  elections  next  year, 
elections often reduce the time horizons of politicians, 
leading  them  to  avoid  new  policy  initiatives  in  the 
preelection  period  and  shifting  their  focus  to  populist 
short-term measures. This could undermine the reform 
agenda contained in the DPSP-4. There is, however, also 
the  possibility  of  a  countervailing  tendency  where  the 
prospect  of  approaching  elections  spurs  political 
entrepreneurs  into  more  clearly  establishing  reform 
credentials and recording clear accomplishments. 
(iv) Heightened  security  risks.  Alerts  stemming  from 
sectarian and regional conflicts and terrorism could slow 
foreign  direct  investment  and  set  back  the  recovering 
tourism industry. The Government and law enforcement 
authorities have taken a range of measures aimed at 
rebuilding public and investor confidence.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of Indonesia for the Fourth Development Policy Support Program (DPSP-4). The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  THE MACROECONOMIC, SOCIAL, AND GOVERNANCE CONTEXT 
A.  Macroeconomic Developments 
2.  Ten years after the Asian financial crisis and domestic political turmoil, Indonesia has 
emerged economically stronger, more democratic, and increasingly resilient to both internal and 
external shocks. In the past 5 years in particular, the country has performed impressively in 
terms of macroeconomic management and political stability has become more entrenched, as 
the democratic process has deepened and achieved wider acceptance. Progressively higher 
gross domestic product (GDP) growth has led since 2005 to per capita real GDP exceeding 
precrisis levels. Prudent macroeconomic management has resulted in lower budget deficits, a 
much lower debt–GDP ratio, and manageable inflation, until recently. The financial sector has 
largely recovered from the 1998 crisis and market sentiment appears largely positive. Exports 
are at record levels, the balance of payments position is strong, and foreign reserves are at 
historic highs. In addition, investment, while still low by historical standards, is rising fast. 
Despite the current global economic slowdown, real GDP accelerated to a 10-year high of 6.3% 
in  2007.  However,  recent  growth  has  not  translated  into  commensurate  increases  in 
employment and reductions in poverty, and nearly half of the population remains vulnerable to 
poverty. The challenge is to build on the foundations of macroeconomic and social stability; and 
accelerate growth to reduce unemployment, poverty, and overall levels of vulnerability.  
 
3.  To achieve these objectives, the Government is pursuing a pro-growth agenda while 
pushing forward on broad structural and institutional reforms. Progress has been made on all 
fronts, albeit unevenly in some areas. Despite recent improvements, there is a continued need 
to  improve  the  investment  climate,  public  financial  management,  and  service  delivery 
mechanisms  to  the  poor.  The  DPSP  series  has  allowed  the  Government  to  work  with 
development partners in a flexible manner to implement critical high-level macroeconomic and 
crosscutting sector reforms that address constraints to growth and poverty reduction while 
providing predictability of financial support. As such, its coverage is fairly broad. Governance is 
a recurring theme throughout the DPSP series, as it aims to promote transparency in all its core 
policy areas. The proposed DPSP-4 is anchored in the country strategy and program (CSP) of 
the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB), 1  which  in  turn  provides  for  deeper  sector-level 
interventions to complement the macroeconomic and governance reforms supported through 
the DPSP series. The DPSP-4 builds on past DPSP operations to support the Government 
further  on  key  reform  measures  in  the  core  areas  of  investment  climate,  public  financial 
management and anticorruption, and service delivery to the poor.  
 
4.  Sustained  Macroeconomic  Performance.  Indonesia’s  growth  performance  has 
remained strong, despite a deteriorating global environment. Having recorded its highest growth 
rate in a decade of 6.3% in 2007, the growth momentum was sustained at 6.4% during the first 
semester of 2008. The main drivers of growth were private consumption, and gross fixed capital 
formation, including a sharp rise in foreign direct investment. While still below precrisis levels, 
                                                 
 
1  ADB. 2006. Country Strategy and Program (2006–2009): Indonesia. Manila.

2   
investment has steadily increased from 19% of GDP immediately after the crisis to 25% of GDP 
in 2007. Encouragingly, since 2007 investment growth has been dominated by a sharp increase 
in plant and machinery, auguring well for future production capacity.  
 
5.  Despite the global economic crisis, Indonesia’s macroeconomic fundamentals held up 
reasonably well during the first 8 months of the year. Indonesia’s balance of payments remained 
in strong surplus in 2007, with the current account recording a surplus of 2.5% of GDP. Exports 
jumped by 31% during the first 6 months of 2008 because of higher commodity prices and 
volume growth. However, reflecting strong domestic consumer and investment growth, imports 
more than doubled during this period, resulting in a small deficit in the current account in the 
second quarter of 2008. Foreign direct investment continued to remain strong during this period 
and reserves were at an all-time high of $60.5 billion at the end of July 2008, before moderating 
to $50.6 billion by end-October, as the Government attempted to stabilize the rupiah amid the 
global financial turmoil (para. 9). However, public debt has continued to fall as a share of GDP 
to below 35% in 2007 and is likely to approach 30% in 2008. Total external debt is also falling, 
most likely to be a little below 30% of GDP in 2008. The budget deficit remains moderate 
despite significant changes in the underlying parameters (para. 7).  
 
6.  Like its neighbors, Indonesia’s inflation has risen sharply since the beginning of the year, 
to 11.8% year-on-year in October 2008. While much of the increase in inflation has been 
attributed to higher food prices2 (food items accounting for nearly 40% of the consumer price 
index), a 28.7% increase in administered fuel prices in late May 2008 added to subsequent 
inflationary pressures both directly and indirectly through generalized price setting. To address 
such pressures, Bank Indonesia has gradually tightened monetary policy by a series of 25 basis 
point increases in interest rates that have led to its policy rate increasing from 8.0% in May 2008 
to 9.5% in October 2008. 
 
7.  Indonesia’s fiscal performance has remained strong despite pressure from increasing 
energy subsidies. Energy (fuel and electricity) subsidies rose to 3% of GDP in 2007. The fiscal 
deficit was, however, contained at 1.3% of GDP, slightly below the deficit of 1.5% projected in 
the revised budget. Energy subsidies increased sharply in 2008 as the oil price assumption in 
the budget was raised from an original $60 to $95, and then again to $110 per barrel. After oil 
prices passed the $110 per barrel threshold, the Government raised regulated fuel prices by an 
average of 28.7% in late May. It is applying part of the saving to fund an unconditional cash 
transfer that offsets rising food costs for 70 million of the country’s poor and near-poor. The 
Government is using most of the remainder to reduce this year’s budget deficit. The oil price 
hike in May, combined with the recent decline in international oil prices, has helped contain 
energy subsidies in 2008. Most of these subsidies are highly regressive—the richest fifth of 
households directly receive as much as two-thirds of Indonesia’s fuel subsidy. Higher levels of 
fossil fuel subsidies also create a disincentive to invest in renewable sources of energy and 
energy efficiency measures, producing a detrimental impact on the environment. A few selected 
food and agriculture items are also subsidized, but such outlays account for a relatively small 
share of total subsides. The real cost of the subsidies is the lost opportunity to invest increased 
oil and gas revenues in the higher priority social and infrastructure areas, needed to sustain 
Indonesia’s  longer-term  growth  and  development  objectives.  In  2008,  development 
                                                 
 
2  Rice had been the exception. Import restrictions in 2005 and 2006 left domestic rice prices almost 50% higher than 
international prices in late 2007. As a result, when international rice prices started rising in early 2008, the price of 
rice in Indonesia did not rise in parallel. However, the continued sharp increases in global rice prices reversed this 
relationship and domestic rice prices started rising again.

3
expenditures—comprising capital and social spending—are projected to amount to 2.8% of 
GDP, slightly below the 2007 level. The Government is well aware of the need to reduce the 
cost of fuel subsidies and has indicated that steps will be taken in the future to address this 
issue.  Efforts  are  under  way  to  contain  subsidized  fuel  consumption  by  possibly  capping 
purchases of subsidized fuels to certain amounts and to replace heavily subsidized kerosene 
with the more economical LPG as the main cooking fuel. The proposed budget for 2009 also 
introduces other  measures  such  as  sharing  the  cost  of  energy  subsidies  with  subnational 
governments, and linking domestic fuel prices with international prices when prices exceed a 
certain threshold. The latest tentative projections for 2008 indicate a deficit of about 1.2%, lower 
than the 2.1% deficit indicated in the revised budget (Table 1). This in part is based on buoyant 
revenue performance and expenditure savings.  Revenues are likely to exceed targets by 
around 5.0% reflecting improved tax administration, and an increase in oil production and 
consequent rise in oil revenues.  Expenditures are likely to come in below the budgeted levels 
due to reduced oil subsidies on account of the recent decline in oil prices, and a 10% cut in 
routine Government expenditures.

8.  Notwithstanding moderate fiscal deficits, Indonesia’s gross borrowing needs during the 
next  2  years  remain  high  because  of  high  levels  of  domestic  and  foreign  debt  principal 
repayments (Table 2). Given that these financing needs coincide with higher domestic and 
international borrowing costs, program loans from development partners provide a preferred 
contribution to Indonesia’s overall financing needs. In 2008, ADB will provide the Government

4   
with $830 million in program loans, while the Government of Japan will provide $500 million and 
the World Bank a further $1,600 million in budget support (amounting to $900 million in program 
loans and a further $700 million in budget support utilizing country systems).

9.  The global economic turmoil has had a significant impact on Indonesia. The structure of 
Indonesia’s financial sector and exports would have, however, suggested that the country was 
better equipped than some of its neighbors to confront the current downturn. The banking sector 
had limited direct exposure to developments in the United States financial markets, low reliance 
on  external  financing, and  had  low  levels  of  nonperforming  loans  (3.4%)  and  high capital 
adequacy ratios (17.1%) in August 2008. Indonesia’s trade share at 50% of GDP is also 
relatively  small,  while  the  structure  and  destination  of  its  exports  potentially  offered  some 
protection to its external sector from the global slowdown. Almost two-thirds of Indonesia’s 
exports are commodities, whose prices had remained strong for much of the year. Indonesia’s 
exports have also been increasingly moving toward economies in Asia and away from the US 
(12.3% of total exports in 2007) and European Union (14.5% of total exports in 2007). However, 
export growth has moderated in recent months as commodity prices have weakened and the 
global economic outlook has deteriorated.  Domestic capital markets have also been subject to 
periodic bouts of volatility since the beginning of 2008, and capital flight since October 2008. By 
the end of September 2008, the Indonesian stock exchange had fallen by 33% since the start of 
the year, and by 7 November the stock exchange had fallen by a further 27% from end-
September levels. A lower risk appetite for emerging market debt, higher domestic inflation, and 
tighter credit markets have adversely affected sentiment, with spreads on Indonesian 5-year 
credit default swaps increasing from 352.7 on 1 October 2008 to 1,256.7 on 23 October 2008, 
before  moderating  to  620.8  on  7  November  2008.  These  developments  have  impacted 
negatively on government debt markets, with yields on government bonds having risen on 
average by 1,021 basis points by end-October, before moderating to 609 basis points by 7 
November 2008. The rupiah, which had remained broadly stable against the US dollar during 
the first 9 months of 2008 has, however, continued to decline since end-September and has 
depreciated by 18% as of 7 November 2008. 
 
10.  GDP growth is expected to moderate to 6.1% in 2008 and 5.2% in 2009, as export 
growth  and  foreign  direct  investment  slows  with  the  global  economic  downturn  (Table  3). 
Growth during this period will be sustained by domestic consumption demand. However, the 
possibility of a prolonged and more severe slump in the global economy holds considerable 
downside  risks  to  Indonesia.  A  sharper  slowdown  in  the  global  economy  and  continued 
turbulence in international financial markets would further affect demand for Indonesian exports 
and limit investment growth as credit markets tighten. Tighter credit markets and increased risk 
aversion could also limit the Government’s ability to tap international financial markets. This has

5
already forced the Government to revise the 2009 budget to target a deficit of 1% of GDP.  The 
Government plans to do this by reducing routine line ministry spending by a further 5% to 15%, 
while maintaining infrastructure spending and scaling up social-sector spending, in particular for 
its flagship community-based poverty alleviation program.  The Government is considering 
various alternative budget financing modalities in view of the tightening financial markets.  
 
11.  The Government has also announced a raft of policy measures to counter the effects of 
the  crisis,  and  boost  liquidity  and  confidence  in  the  financial  system.  These  include  the 
relaxation of reserve requirements for commercial banks and the use of central bank and 
government  debt  as  secondary  reserves,  the  lowering  of  reserve  requirements  on  foreign 
exchange deposits, the extension of the tenor on foreign exchange swaps from 7 days to 
1 month, abolishing the limits placed on the daily balance position of short-term foreign loans, 
increasing the ceiling on deposit insurance from Rp.100 million to Rp.2 billion, and easing rules 
for  share  buybacks  for  companies  with  share  price  declines.  The  Government  has  also 
implemented a regulation strengthening the legal basis and interagency coordination in dealing 
with the financial crisis, including on decisions relating to injecting liquidity and whether to bail 
out troubled banks. In the real sector, the Government has provided various tax incentives for 
investment,  and  has  initiated  measures  to  accelerate  state  budget  disbursements  and 
procurement (both areas supported by this program loan).

B.  Social and Governance Context 
12.  Translating  Growth  into  Poverty  Reduction  and  Employment  Generation. 
Indonesia’s poverty rate, measured with reference to the national poverty line, fell from 16.6% in 
March 2007 to 15.4% in March 2008. The decrease resumed the trend of gradually declining 
poverty rates since 2000, which had been interrupted in 2006 by a nearly 2 percentage point 
increase caused by a sharp rise in rice prices. Both urban and rural poverty declined over the 
course  of  2007;  the  decline  was  spatially  quite  uniform,  with  even  the  poorest  provinces 
registering decreases in their poverty rates. These levels of poverty, however, translate to about 
35 million poor people, while nearly half the population could be considered among the poor or 
near-poor because their per capita consumption levels were less than one-third above the 
national poverty line. These figures suggest that there is a very large group of near-poor in 
Indonesia who are highly vulnerable to shocks at all levels. The poverty profile in Indonesia still 
indicates considerable regional differences in poverty—nine provinces have poverty rates of 
less than 10% (4.3% in Jakarta) while 10 provinces have poverty rates of more than 20% (37%

6   
in Papua). A challenge for the Government is that, while the poverty incidence is far higher in 
eastern regions, most of Indonesia’s poor live in the densely populated and relatively more 
prosperous western regions. Indonesia’s labor market may also be turning the corner and the 
phenomenon of “jobless growth” may be easing. The employment numbers from the latest 
(February  2008)  national  labor  force  survey  indicate  improvements  in  many  labor  market 
outcomes, continuing what appears now to be an improving trend since 2005. The employment 
rate, the share of the labor force with nonfarm employment, as well as the share with formal 
jobs have all been rising, while the open unemployment rate has fallen to 8.5% in February 
2008 from 9.8% a year earlier. 
 
13.  Non-Income Millennium Development Goals. Indonesia’s progress toward meeting 
other Millennium Development Goal (MDG) targets is somewhat mixed. Malnutrition remains a 
significant  public  health  problem,  with  the  percentage  of  children  under  5  years  who  are 
underweight rising from 24.6% in 2000 to 28.0% in 2005. This has been attributed in part to 
decentralization in 2000, since the responsibilities for the previous highly centralized family 
nutrition programs were devolved to more than 400 districts. This created difficulties in planning, 
financing, and supervising these programs. On the MDG goal relating to education, Indonesia is 
well on track to achieve the target in primary net enrollment, but it is falling behind in achieving 
net  enrollment  in  lower  secondary  education.  In  relation  to  the  MDG  on  gender  equality, 
Indonesia is on track to achieve gender equality in education. The gender gaps in terms of net 
enrollment  rates  in  primary  and  lower  secondary  education  have  already  been  closed. 
Measured in terms of labor market participation in the nonagricultural sector and seats in 
Parliament, however, participation of women continues to lag behind that of men. Indonesia is 
also on track to achieve the MDG target of reducing the under-5 mortality rate by two-thirds by 
2015, but progress in reducing the maternal mortality ratio has not been sufficient to meet the 
levels targeted in the MDGs. While the country remains on track for achieving the targets for 
improved drinking water, it is off track with regard to attaining the target on access to improved 
sanitation facilities. The country is severely off track in achieving the targets of reversing forestry 
loss. In most of the MDG-related indicators, sharp regional and socioeconomic differentials 
remain and progress in many instances remains less than has been achieved by the relatively 
more advanced economies of Southeast Asia.  
 
14.  Translating  Growth  into  Equity  and  Efficiency—Progress  in  Governance. 
Subnational elections held over the past years have mostly been well run and peaceful, and 
have often led to losses for incumbents, demonstrating the electorates’ willingness to punish 
poor performance. At the national level, policy debate is often vigorous and political parties are 
developing stronger identities. This political stability and public debate are proving conducive to 
gradually improving governance and economic growth that is more sustainable. Indonesia’s 
governance indicators have improved markedly in recent years but there is still scope for much 
more improvement, and despite recent advances, corruption remains a significant obstacle to 
doing business. 
 
15.  Several high-profile cases led by the Corruption Eradication Commission anti-corruption 
commission  (KPK)  are  advancing  the  Government’s  corruption-fighting  credentials.  One 
involved the transfer of funds from Bank Indonesia to members of parliamentary committees to 
influence the passing of several bills, including one that would have transferred responsibility for 
supervising the financial sector from Bank Indonesia to a separate agency. In a separate case, 
an attempt by senior members of a large conglomerate to influence the Attorney General’s 
office  has  seen  KPK  arrest  the  businesspeople,  and  many  attorney  generals  and  state 
prosecutors have been reassigned or dismissed. Various customs offices have been raided and 
customs officials arrested for suspect payments. In addition, regional government officials are

7
being prosecuted for corruption, such as one case of a protected mangrove area being rezoned 
for a port development. 
 
16.  In  addition  to  pursuing  past  cases,  the  Government  is  also  gradually  introducing 
measures to prevent corruption. Senior public servants in the Ministry of Finance (MOF) may no 
longer also hold senior positions in state-owned enterprises (SOEs). Throughout the public 
service, pay levels are being brought closer to the skill and responsibility of the position, and the 
private sector equivalents. Vacancies are being filled through internal advertisements rather 
than automatic promotion. 
 
17.  Indonesia’s democratic governance made major advances in 2004 with its first direct 
presidential election, and all indicators suggest that the national elections in 2009 will repeat 
those achievements. Nevertheless, the 2009 elections increase the uncertainties surrounding 
the conduct of policy over the next year, and its longer-term direction. On the one hand, the 
election process could place on hold certain reforms with longer-term returns, or with high short-
term  costs  to  vocal  sectional  interests,  such  as  reducing  Indonesia’s  very  large  energy 
subsidies. On the other, more legislative measures may be passed as the preelection pressure 
mounts for the Government to demonstrate its achievements. 
 
III.  GOVERNMENT STRATEGY, PROGRAM STRUCTURE, AND RESULTS 
A.  The Development Policy Support Program and Government Strategy 
18.  The DPSP supports the development policy agenda of the Development Policy Loan 
(DPL) series prepared by a joint team of the Government of Indonesia, ADB, Government of 
Japan, and the World Bank.3 The DPL series aims to help the Government achieve its medium-
term growth and poverty reduction objectives through three core policy areas: (i) improved 
investment  climate,  (ii)  improved  public  financial  management  and  governance,  and  (iii) 
improved delivery of public services to the poor. Building on the support provided by the DPSP-
3 (approved in December 2007), the proposed DPSP-4 will provide parallel cofinancing support 
to the Government to help implement reforms under the fifth Development Policy Loan (DPL-5), 
which is the fifth in a series of five annual, single-tranche loans. 
 
19.  The Government’s national medium-term development plan (RPJM) aims to achieve 
peace and security, justice and democracy, while advancing the welfare of the people within the 
time frame of 2004–2009. The RPJM includes the eight MDGs that provide an overarching 
framework, placing human development and poverty reduction at the center of the development 
agenda. The RPJM has set a number of social targets, some of which are more ambitious than 
the MDGs. For example, it aims to halve the 2004 national poverty rate from 16.6% to 8.2% by 
2009. The Government’s work plan (RKP), approved each year by the cabinet, guides RPJM 
implementation. The RKPs set out annual development priorities, including quantitative targets 
and policy directions, which in turn provide a guide to aggregate budgetary allocations.4  
 
                                                 
 
3  As ADB did not participate in DPL-1, a different title—DPSP—has been adopted for ADB’s operations. Thus, the 
equivalence is as follows: DPL-1 = ADB’s participation through policy dialogue; DPL-2 = DPSP-1; DPL-3 = 
DPSP-2; DPL-4 = DPSP-3; and DPL-5 = DPSP-4. The proposed Program is in line with ADB’s CSP 2006–2009 for 
Indonesia, which supports continued cofinancing of the DPLs. 
4  In an apparent recognition of the difficulty of attaining the poverty target, the 2009 RKP sets a target of reducing 
the poverty rate to 12%–14% in 2009 from 15.4% in March 2008.

8   
20.  The  RKP  for  2008  indicates  that  the  overall  development  theme  for  next  year  is 
“Accelerated Economic Growth for Job Creation and Poverty Reduction”. To address this overall 
theme,  the  RKP  for  2008  has  the  following  eight  priority  areas:  (i)  increasing  investment, 
exports,  and  job  opportunities;  (ii)  revitalizing  agriculture,  fisheries,  forestry,  and  rural 
development;  (iii)  accelerating  development  of  infrastructure  and  improvement  of  energy 
management; (iv) improving access and quality of education and health services; (v) improving 
the effectiveness of poverty reduction measures; (vi) corruption eradication and accelerated 
bureaucratic reform; (vii) strengthening defense capabilities and improving domestic security; 
and (viii) disaster response, disaster risk reduction, and improvement of avian influenza control. 
Of these, the first, fourth, fifth, and sixth priority areas relate to the core policy areas of the 
DPSP-4. ADB’s Infrastructure Reform Sector Development Program addresses the priority area 
related to infrastructure5. 
 
21.  To help implement the RKP priorities, economic policy packages have been introduced 
in each of the last 3 years, from which specific measures are derived to be achieved within a 
defined period. In 2006, the Government issued three economic policy packages covering 
investment climate, infrastructure, and financial sector reform. In 2007, a comprehensive follow-
up package was issued detailing measures to accelerate development, and empower micro, 
small, and medium-sized enterprises. The latest package, introduced in May 2008, builds on the 
previous packages and details reforms in the following eight areas: (i) investment climate; 
(ii) financial sector; (iii) energy security; (iv) natural resources, environment, and agriculture; 
(v) small  and  medium-sized  enterprises  (SME);  (vi)  implementation  of  the  Association  of 
Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN)  commitments;  (vii)  infrastructure;  and  (viii) labor  policy. 
Through these policy packages, the Government has demonstrated a clear willingness to deal 
with a number of complex, and in some cases politically sensitive, issues that have been on 
hold for some time. Each policy package has time-bound actions and stipulates a minister to be 
responsible for each item. The packages also represent a foundation for future DPL/DPSPs, 
which are envisioned to deepen the policy dialogue in select areas. The triggers for the DPSP-4 
include several actions identified in the policy packages. 
 
22.  The DPSP Series, Other ADB Sector Programs, and Donor Harmonization. Support 
for the RPJM through parallel cofinancing of the DPL series is a key pillar of ADB’s CSP for 
2006–2009 (footnote 1). Under the CSP, a dual-track approach is adopted to ensure that the 
high-level macroeconomic and governance reforms supported through the policy dialogue of the 
DPL series complement, and are reinforced by, ADB’s sector programs. Underpinning the policy 
dialogue has been a series of advisory technical assistance (TA) provided by the World Bank 
and ADB that the Government has drawn upon. Figure 1 presents the approach, which involves 
structuring ADB’s support through (i) participation in the DPLs to strengthen the macroeconomic 
and fiscal framework while addressing crosscutting concerns; and (ii) sector-specific policy 
interventions in the areas of infrastructure, financial deepening, local government finance, and 
poverty reduction and accelerated progress toward the MDGs. ADB’s dual-track approach aims 
to harmonize and align development partner strategies with Indonesia’s country strategy and 
priorities. The participation of ADB and the Government of Japan in the World Bank-coordinated 
DPL series, and the participation of the Government of Japan and the World Bank in ADB’s 
Infrastructure Reform Sector Development Program, have helped reduce the Government’s 
transaction costs of policy dialogue with three of the country’s most important development 
partners.  Moreover,  development  partner  harmonization  around  the  Government’s  own 
                                                 
 
5 ADB. 2008. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan to the 
Republic of Indonesia for the Infrastructure Reform Sector Development Program (Subprogram 2). Manila

9
programs has bolstered country ownership of the reform process and helped change the nature 
of the relationship with the three development partners to one of reliable collaboration. ADB’s 
active participation in the policy discussions in all areas of the DPL and the parallel policy 
dialogue on sector reforms have been particularly appreciated by the Government, as these 
have helped in setting the overall macroeconomic framework for sector-level reforms supported 
by  ADB.  ADB’s  engagement  in  these  policy  discussions  and  its  strength  in  the  areas  of 
infrastructure, financial sector, decentralization, and support for achieving MDGs have helped 
avoid duplication of effort and improved the monitoring as well as the quality of the triggers. 
B.  The Evolution of the Program 
23.  At its inception in 2004, the DPL series was designed to support Indonesia’s transition 
from postcrisis stabilization to more long-term development. The DPL was expected to provide 
the foundation for continued, medium-term policy engagement in the areas of macroeconomic 
stability, the investment climate, and public financial management and anticorruption. It also 
provided for a flexible means of taking into account the pace and fluidity of the reform process. 
Hence, as the program has evolved, the scope of the reform agenda has become broader. The 
broadening of the agenda has also been accompanied by a deepening of reforms, whereby 
successive DPL operations have built on previous ones to ensure incremental implementation. 
The  theme  of  the  DPL-1  was  on  restoring  and  maintaining  macroeconomic  stability  and 
consolidating macroeconomic achievements at a time when Indonesia was leaving its postcrisis 
International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  program.  Within  this  context,  the  main  focus  was  on 
macroeconomic  stability  and  creditworthiness,  investment  climate,  and  public  financial 
management and governance. The theme of the DPL-2/DPSP-1 progressed toward creating 
fiscal space. This led to themes more focused on implementation. The emphasis of the DPL-
3/DPSP-2 was on utilizing the fiscal space that had been created in the DPL-2 to have a greater 
impact on service delivery, while the theme of the DPL-4/DPSP-3 carried this further forward by 
deepening the process of institutional reform Reflecting the flexibility of the program and the 
Government’s success in achieving macroeconomic stability and attaining the macroeconomic 
triggers of the DPL program ahead of time, the Government and development partners agreed 
in early 2006 to remove the macroeconomic pillar in the proposed DPL-4/DPSP-3, but to 
continue the policy dialogue on macroeconomic stability. At the same time, the increased fiscal 
space  generated  by  the  reduction  in  fuel  subsidies,  declining  debt  service  payments,  and 
increasing revenues had opened up opportunities for a greater focus on public service delivery 
as a new policy area (Appendix 2 provides the evolution of DPL/DPSP triggers). 
C.  Results Achieved 
24.  Policy  actions  under  the  macroeconomic  pillar  relating  to  debt  and  fiscal  policy 
management  contributed  considerably  to  lower  levels  of  debt  to  GDP  and  a  considerable 
increase in non-oil tax revenues6. Rating agencies have also cited debt reduction and the 
Government’s commitment to reforms, including changes to the investment law, customs and 
tax reforms, and fiscal reforms—all activities supported by the DPL/DPSP—as the reason for 
recent sovereign rating upgrades. Policy actions supported under the investment climate have 
led to significant improvements in business start-up times, value-added tax (VAT) refund times, 
and have led to the establishment of a sounder and sustainable financial safety net. DPL/DPSP 
                                                 
 
6  This section, and the subsequent section on Lessons, is based on the findings of a program completion report 
undertaken for the DPSP-1 in 2008, and discussions that ADB held with the World Bank and the Government for 
the preparation of a separate program completion report for the DPSP-2, and the DPSP-3 in 2009 (Appendix 3).

10  
policy  measures  have  also  supported  revisions  to  the  Tax  Law,  the  implementing  decree 
relating to tax audit procedures, implementation decrees supporting the investment law, and the 
rollout  of  a  national  single  window  (NSW)  with  online  clearance  of  merchandise.  A  key 
achievement under the public financial management pillar has been the implementation of the 
treasury single account (TSA) to improve cash management of public finances. The DPL/DPSP 
program has helped move forward reforms to reengineer business processes across the budget 
cycle.  The  national  budget  is  now  compatible  with  the  international  standard  government 
finance statistics (GFS) classification. Fiscal reporting is more comprehensive and timely, and 
elements of a medium-term expenditure framework (MTEF) have been introduced, though not 
fully operational in the budget system. Initial steps to address civil service reform have been 
launched under the DPL/DPSP series. As an initial measure, the DPL/DPSP supported the 
development of a comprehensive reform of the structure and remuneration framework for high-
ranking state officials. A task force was set up to examine the entire compensation package with 
the goal of creating a more transparent, systematic, and coherent framework for pay and 
allowances based on a comprehensive job evaluation and pay grading. Building on this, MOF 
has developed a comprehensive civil service reform action plan, which is being pilot tested in 
other agencies. Important steps were also established under the DPL/DPSP series to help lay 
the groundwork for improving poverty targeting of basis services. As the 2005 fuel price hike 
made available more funds for social spending, the DPL/DPSP supported building capacity in 
government institutions to create a more evaluative institutional framework that would improve 
the targeting of these released funds. Lessons from targeting were incorporated into the new 
cash transfer program that accompanied the May 2008 fuel price increase. The DPSP/DPL has 
also supported critical actions to improve the quality of public service delivery in education and 
community-based development. 
D.  Lessons 
25.  Donor  coordination.  The  DPL/DPSP  facility  provided  a  useful  platform  for  donor 
coordination  of  policies  and  programs.  The  Government  welcomed  the  development  of  a 
consistent approach to critical reform issues among key donors. Sharing of technical advisory 
support, information, and data that had implications for cooperation in other operational areas 
took place among donors (notably in programs to support infrastructure development, where 
ADB took the lead role). 
 
26.  Coordination within Government. The negotiations to develop the DPL/DPSP and the 
need  to  develop  joint  positions  on  policy  issues  necessitated  regular  and  continuous 
interagency consultation and coordination that may have indirectly led to systemic changes in 
the policy coordination process within key agencies of the Government. This was noted by 
stakeholders during the current review process. 
 
27.  The Role of Policy Triggers. Although these represented actions that the Government 
fully intended to undertake independently, the choice of outcomes/triggers was important in 
guiding both the direction and pace of the reform process within the Government. The inclusion 
of a trigger/outcome in the DPL/DPSP was welcomed by those pushing for particular reforms 
within the Government, as this would increase the political profile of the reform and this could 
help ensure the maintenance of the momentum needed to achieve the reform. At the same 
time, the process of identifying triggers was sometimes used by reformers to unrealistically 
overpromise to push through as much of the reforms as possible without regard to meeting the 
deadline of the prior actions.

11
28.  The Importance of Continuity in the Reform Process, Building on Earlier Changes. 
Some  reforms—such  as  the  TSA—led  to  solid  progress  on  a  reform  objective,  and  the 
DPL/DPSP played a clear role in their achievement. These reforms are also more sustainable, 
as the reforms progressed and were deepened, and the parties involved remained engaged in 
the reform process. 
 
29.  The Design and Specification of Specific Triggers. The wording of each policy action 
required under the program was developed on the basis of mutual trust and understanding 
between the Government and the three development partners, with a clear understanding of the 
direction  of  reforms,  without  excessive  specificity  that  would  create  political  difficulties  or 
compromise the flexibility of the Government in overcoming obstacles to reform. This was 
especially important in areas where the executing agency (MOF) or the agencies working most 
closely  with  it  Coordinating  Ministry  of  Economic  Affairs  (CMEA)  and  Bappenas  National 
Development Planning Agency) had no direct control over implementation of a particular reform, 
as other agencies or Parliament were involved. 
 
30.  Strengthening Change Management Capacity in the Government and Identifying 
Key Change Management Points. The success of the DPL/DPSP programs has hinged on the 
proactive  role  taken  by  key  counterparts  willing  to  take  up  difficult  change  management 
functions. This has involved a strong communications strategy with all concerned stakeholders, 
making  assessments  of  potential  gains  and  losses  to  key  stakeholders,  having  realistic 
assessments of the time frames required to implement specific actions, and identifying potential 
risks and obstacles as well as remedial and palliative actions. It was widely recognized that 
supporting the agencies leading the reform process (through advisory services or technical 
support) would yield disproportionately large benefits in terms of the facilitation of future reforms 
and the formulation and design of the Government’s forward-looking reform agenda. DPL/DPSP 
reforms have tended to be most successful in areas where they were complemented by a 
strong TA program.

IV.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
31.  The impact of the DPSP-4 will be in the form of higher economic growth that is sustained 
over the medium term and accompanied by lower levels of unemployment and poverty. Its main 
outcome is improved overall economic management anchored on good governance through 
(i) an improved investment climate, (ii) improved public financial management, and (iii) improved 
delivery of public services. 
 
32.  The design and monitoring framework for the DPSP-4 is in Appendix 1. The letter of 
development policy for DPSP-4 is in Appendix 4, and the policy matrix is in Appendix 5. 
Appendix 6 presents the development partners coordination matrix, outlining support from ADB 
and other development partners in areas related to the DPSP series, while Appendix 9 presents 
the summary poverty reduction and social strategy. 
B.  Policy Framework and Actions 
33.  The DPSP-4 is in substantive terms a continuation of DPSPs 1–3, the programmatic 
series  of  annual  single-tranche  operations  from  2005  to  2007.7 The  proposed  Program 
continues the policy dialogue on, and support to, Indonesia’s reform program in the three core 
areas  that  were  the  focus  of  the  DPSP-3:  (i)  the  investment  climate,  (ii)  public  financial 
management  and  governance,  and  (iii)  improved  delivery  of  public  services  to  the  poor. 
Improvements in the investment climate are critical to accelerating growth; public financial 
management and civil service reforms are essential for enhancing government effectiveness in 
a decentralized and democratic Indonesia. In addition, improving service delivery and poverty 
alleviation efforts is essential if Indonesia is to bring about more broad-based improvements in 
welfare for all its population.  
 
34.  All the triggers in these three areas were chosen as part of the dialogue with the 
Government during preparation of the DPSP-3, and represent a natural next step from those 
that were achieved in that program. The policy and reform focus of these triggers have further 
evolved  and  moved  progressively  forward  to  include  improved  regulations,  increased 
transparency, and deepened institutions prerequisites to sustain medium-term growth and social 
development. The DPSP-3 program document laid out 17 indicative triggers (prior actions) 
across nine policy areas for the DPSP-4. Satisfactory progress has been made on all the 
triggers, with two having exceeded requirements (Table 4).8  
                                                 
 
7  As originally envisaged in the Indonesia CSP, there was to be no DPSP loan in 2008, with the last loan in the 
series (DPSP-4) programmed for 2009. However, based on a government request for ADB to participate in the 
DPL process in 2008, the proposed loan in 2009 was advanced to 2008, and a new loan for 2009 (DPSP-5) has 
been programmed in the Indonesia country operations business plan (ADB. 2008. Country Operations Business 
Paln (2009—2011): Indonesia. Manila), to coincide with the ending of the Government’s medium-term development 
plan 2004—2009.   
8  In keeping with the DPL modality, which has been characterized by medium-term engagement, strong country 
ownership, and continuous policy dialogue with the Government, triggers are used in a more process-oriented and 
flexible sense with less of a focus on compliance with conditions. International experience with policy-based 
lending and recent literature on the subject suggests that a focus on traditional conditionality could undermine 
country ownership and the sustainability of the reform process (World Bank. 2005. Conditionality Revisited. 
Washington,  DC;  ADB.  2007.  Special  Evaluation  Study  on  Policy-Based  Lending:  Emerging  Practices  in 
Supporting Reforms in Developing Member Countries. Manila).

1.  Core Policy Area I: Improved Investment Climate 
35.  Investment growth accelerated in 2007, rising to 9.2% from just 2.5% the previous year 
and accounting for one-third of total economic growth. As a share of GDP, investment reached 
25%, a major improvement from 19% immediately after the Asian financial crisis, but still not a 
full recovery to pre-crisis levels of nearly 30% of GDP, and considerably below the investment 
rates  of  countries  such  as  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (45%)  and  Viet  Nam  (32%). 
Investment growth continued to accelerate during the first semester of 2008, reaching 14.1%, 
and contributing 41% to GDP growth.  
 
36.  Some of the impetus for recent strong investment trends may be coming from higher 
foreign direct investment. The Investment Board reports that realized foreign investment nearly 
doubled from $5.9 billion in 2006 to $10.4 billion in 2007, and increased by nearly 2.5 times to 
$10.4 billion during January–June 2008 (from $4.1 billion during the same period in 2007).  
 
37.  Business  perceptions  of  the  investment  climate,  especially  those  relating  to 
improvements in macroeconomic stability and economic policy, may explain part of the recent

16  
recovery of investment. The annual survey of the Japan Bank for International Cooperation of 
600 Japanese multinational companies also showed an improvement in Indonesia’s global 
ranking  in  2007,  following  4 straight  years  of  decline,  with  Japanese  multinationals  rating 
Indonesia as the eighth most promising country for overseas investment.  
 
38.  Part of this improvement in perceptions may be due to the economic reform programs 
introduced by the Government over the past 3 years (Appendix 3). Major achievements under 
these packages include the Investment Law, 2007; the Tax Administration Law, 2007; and the 
2008  law  on  electronic  transactions  that  provides  a  legal  basis  for  e-Government.  The 
investment law stipulates equal treatment for foreign and domestic investors and reinforces 
investor protections. 
 
39.  Major reforms in tax administration and customs administration are under way, including 
a  new  VAT  refund  system  that  promises  refunds  in  7 days  for  “golden”  taxpayers,  within 
2 months  for  low-risk  exporters,  and  within  4  months  for  medium-risk  exporters.  Standard 
operating procedures for a complaints management system have also been issued, including a 
code  of  ethics  for  tax  officials.  Implementation  of  a  single  window  for  export  and  import 
documentation was launched on a pilot basis for selected large importers in Indonesia’s main 
seaport in December 2007 and is currently being expanded to additional importers and ports. 
Full  implementation  will  eventually  allow  electronic  submission  and  approval  of  a  single 
combined  customs  form  covering  all  required  clearances,  and  a  consequent  reduction  in 
clearance times. Reforms to the procedures for establishing a limited liability company were 
issued in September 2007, reducing business start-up times from 105 days in 2007 to 76 days 
in 2008. 
 
40.  Notwithstanding these reforms, recent gains have taken place from a low base and 
businesses in Indonesia still face an overall poor business climate. Indonesia’s investment 
climate continues to rank poorly in international comparisons. The World Bank’s Doing Business 
2009 report ranks Indonesia 129 out of 181 countries on the ease of doing business, a drop of 
two places since the 2008 report, and well behind its regional competitors such as Thailand 
(13),  Malaysia  (20),  PRC  (83),  and  Viet  Nam  (92).9 Other  indicators  such  as  the  World 
Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index also show little improvement, with Indonesia’s 
ranking remaining virtually unchanged from 2007 to 2008 (54 out of 131 countries in 2008, 
compared to 51 out of 122 countries in 2007)10. Indonesia’s poor performance in these indices 
reflects the fact that other countries have been making a greater effort to improve their business 
climate relative to Indonesia. Business in Indonesia continues to face a difficult legal and 
regulatory environment, while implementation of policies remains poor because of inefficient 
coordination and capacity constraints in government agencies. Strict labor regulations continue 
to create a disincentive to employment expansion, while lack of access to long-term finance and 
infrastructure weaknesses raises the cost and uncertainty of doing business. The Government 
is attempting to address this issue by forging partnerships with the private sector. To support 
government efforts in this area, ADB is providing TA to strengthen institutions promoting public–
private partnerships (PPPs) in infrastructure provision, and it is providing a loan to fund a project 
development facility that will assist in preparing PPP projects for tendering to the private sector 
on  a  transparent  and  competitive  basis.11 ADB  is  also  providing  assistance  for  long-term

infrastructure financing of PPP projects through the proposed Indonesia Infrastructure Financing 
Facility. 
 
a.  Trigger 1: PEPI to coordinate the development of regulations and technical 
guidelines for effective implementation of the Investment Law by undertaking a 
review of the negative list (Presidential Regulation No. 77/2007), and oversee the 
compilation of a mapping of business licenses in key economic sectors with a view to 
introducing recommendations for specific licenses to be streamlined or eliminated. 
(current status: satisfactory) 
 
41.  The national team to enhance exports and investment (PEPI) under the Coordinating 
Ministry for Economic Affairs has already undertaken a review of the investment negative list 
(Presidential Regulation No. 77/2007), incorporating inputs from the private sector. The new list 
was issued in December 2007 and clarifies that companies existing prior to the issuance of the 
negative  list  were  grandfathered  with  respect  to  new  restrictions.  A  few  sectors,  such  as 
business and management consulting services, were also opened to greater levels of foreign 
investment. The development of technical guidelines for investment procedures and undertaking 
a mapping of business licenses to support license simplification is behind schedule, partly 
because of a delay in obtaining the requisite finances for these activities. Funds have now been 
earmarked and a tender has been issued for a study of sectoral investment regulations that will 
support mapping of business licenses.  
 
b.  Trigger 2: Increase the ability to monitor the investment climate by: (i) posting 
publicly, average processing time for VAT refunds; (ii) making available data on the 
time taken to establish a company from reserving the name to issuing the 
legalization decree; and (iii) designing a system to monitor and report on import 
clearance time from unloading to gate-out combining data from the Port Operator 
and Customs. (current status: achieved) 
 
42.  Directorate General of Taxes (DG Tax) has already published on its website the average 
processing time for a number of taxpayer services, including VAT refunds (broken down by 
taxpayer risk categories: low, medium, and high). Pursuant to Director General Taxes Circular 
Letter 19/PJ/2008, this data will be updated quarterly as part of the tax office key performance 
indicators. The Ministry of Justice has made available data from its SISMINBAKUM database on 
the time taken to establish a company from reserving the name to issuing the legalization 
decree.  Standard  templates  for  reporting  and  publishing  summary  statistics  are  being 
developed. The Customs Department has designed a new data system known as TPS Online 
that will combine customs data with data from terminal operators, thereby allowing more careful 
monitoring of import clearance time. TPS Online is scheduled to go live in December 2008. 
 
c.  Trigger 3: Continue to implement the national single window (NSW), including 
increasing the number of participating agencies and companies.  Extend the original 
pilot (current status: achieved) 
 
43.  Considerable progress has been made in developing the NSW. A national team to 
establish the single window, chaired by the minister of finance and led at the working level by a 
deputy under the coordinating minister for the economy, has been created. A pilot project was 
                                                                                                                                                          
 
Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan to the Republic of Indonesia for the Infrastructure Reform Sector 
Development Program. Manila (Loan 2264-INO[SF], approved November, $26.5 million equivalent).

18  
launched at Jakarta's Tanjung Priok seaport in December 2007, involving 100 priority lane 
companies and customs, the port authority, Ministry of Trade, the Food and Drug Agency, and 
quarantine. In August 2008, this was expanded to an additional 10 government agencies, and 
as of early September 2008, 143 companies were reported to be using the NSW. The pilot has 
been  extended  to  the  three  additional  seaports  as  well  as  the  Jakarta  airport.    The 
Government’s 2008 Economic Policy Package (Presidential Instruction No. 5/2008) targets a 
decision to be made on the operational model for the NSW by December 2008, which will be 
critical for the next stage of implementation. 
 
44.  The NSW for imports and exports is the most important trade facilitation initiative under 
way in Indonesia. Under a single window, traders (importers and exporters) will no longer be 
required to apply individually to multiple government agencies—such as customs, the port 
authority, Ministry of Trade, the Food and Drug Agency, and quarantine—to clear cargoes. A 
single  application  is  instead  submitted  using  a  single  administrative  document  and  this 
application  is  transmitted  to  each  relevant  agency  by  the  operator  of  the  single  window. 
Approval is transmitted back to the operator so that the trader communicates directly with one 
authority rather than multiple authorities. The Indonesian NSW is being established in the 
framework of several ASEAN agreements as an initial step toward an eventual ASEAN single 
window for international trade. 
 
d.  Trigger 4: Issue implementing regulations for the Tax Administration Law and 
monitoring instructions to tax offices.  Establish a system to monitor and report on 
response time for tax audit objections and appeals. (current status: exceeded) 
 
45.  As of September 2008, all implementation regulations for the tax administration law have 
been issued and posted on the DG Tax website, and socialized to tax offices across the 
country.  The Tax Administration Law, 2007, strikes a better balance between the rights and 
obligations of taxpayers and the powers of tax officials—an issue of longstanding concern to the 
business  community.  To  take  effect,  the  law  needed  to  be  supported  by  implementing 
regulations issued by DG Tax and socialized to tax offices across the country. These new 
regulations clarify and provide certainty in the administrative procedures for taxpayers to comply 
with the law, as well as for the tax officials to provide services to taxpayers. 
 
46.  In August 2008, DG Tax published on its website the average processing time for each 
of  the  eight  major  taxpayer  services,  including  tax  objections,  taxpayer  registration,  VAT 
refunds, exemption of withholding tax on imports, and property relief tax. This data on the 
average response times of these major taxpayer services will be updated and monitored by 
DG Tax every quarter. This follows the issuance of Director General of Taxes Circular Letter 
19/PJ/2008 requiring all tax offices to report on a quarterly basis the average time to process 
these taxpayer services as part of its effort to improve taxpayer services and monitor the 
performance of tax offices.  
 
e.  Trigger 5: Continue the tariff harmonization program and implement effective and 
transparent operating procedures, including public disclosure (current status: 
achieved) 
 
47.  Indonesia has been implementing a major tariff harmonization program since 2005 to 
simplify the structure of import tariffs and reduce the number of tariff brackets. The program is 
scheduled to end in 2010. Tim Tarif, the agency reviewing proposals for tariff change, is on 
track  for  its  tariff  harmonization  target  for  2008  as  shown  by  the  MOF  Regulation  (PMK) 
No. 70/PMK.011/2008. As a result of the latest tariff harmonization, in 2008 around 86% of

19
applied tariff lines will be 0%–10% with only 2% of tariffs higher than 35%. In 2008, the simple 
average tariff will be down to 7.7%, compared to 9.9% in 2004. 
 
48.  The Government is showing commitment to improving procedures and transparency in 
reviewing tariff proposals by Tim Tarif by introducing a ministerial decree that dictates the 
maximum time allowed for reviewing tariff proposals, and governs general rules for plenary 
meetings in Tim Tarif (appendix in MOF decree to renew the mandate for Tim Tarif, KMK 
No. 285/KMK.011/2007).  With  respect  to  disclosure,  Tim  Tarif  has  been  disclosing  MOF 
decrees on tariff policies on its website.12 
 
f.  Trigger 6: Issue a government decree specifying a higher capital requirement for 
insurance companies (current status: achieved) 
 
49. Peraturan  Pemerintah  (PP)  or  government  regulation  No.  39/2008  specifying  a  higher 
capital requirement for insurance companies was issued on 19 May 2008. The decree is part of 
the  broader  effort  to  reduce  financial  sector  vulnerabilities  and  improve  the  stability  and 
operations of insurance markets, a key nonbank market needed to spread risk and increase the 
availability of longer-term finance. An earlier regulation in 1999 (PP No. 73/99) had raised the 
minimum  paid-up  capital  to  Rp100  billion  for  insurance  companies  and  Rp200  billion  for 
reinsurance companies (from Rp2 billion for life insurance companies, Rp3 billion for nonlife 
insurance companies, and Rp10 billion for reinsurance companies). However, this regulation 
was only applicable to new companies, which meant that companies that existed before the 
effective  date  of  PP  No.  73/99  were  not  subjected  to  this  regulation.  This  created  unfair 
treatment among companies and unfavorable conditions for industry development. The new 
regulation stipulates that the minimum paid-up capital of Rp100 billion for insurance companies 
and Rp200 billion for reinsurance companies should be applicable to all such companies and 
sets a date of 31 December 2010 for full compliance with this requirement. 
 
g.  Trigger 7: Rationalize SME financing/microfinance schemes across line ministries 
and state-owned enterprises (SOE), including issuing a presidential decree on the 
legal establishment of provincial credit guarantee and re-guarantee institutions 
(current status: achieved) 
 
50.  Access to credit has long been a major constraint to the growth of micro, small, and 
medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) in Indonesia. Numerous line ministries and SOEs have 
tried to run several schemes to finance micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises with limited 
success. On the other hand, the ability of PT Askrindo and Perum Jamkrindo, the two credit 
guarantee institutions set up by the Government to reduce risks to banks, to underwrite new 
business had been severely constrained by the limited availability of capital. The Government 
resolved this issue by injecting capital of Rp1.4 trillion to these companies in late 2007. In 
October 2007, the Government also moved towards rationalizing all SME financing programs of 
line ministries into a unified guarantee scheme by initiating the signing of a memorandum of 
understanding with six banks, five line ministries and the two credit guarantee companies to 
launch the People’s Entrepreneurship Credit Program (KUR) to facilitate partially guarantee 
credits to MSMEs. Under the KUR scheme, the banks will take up 30% of the credit risk and the 
credit guarantee institutions will take the remainder. As of July 2008, disbursements under the 
KUR had reached around Rp9 trillion. In addition, the Government also issued Presidential
