Regulation No. 2/2008 in January 2008 that allowed for the establishment of provincial credit 
guarantee companies and the development of re-guarantee companies. 
2.  Core Policy Area II: Improved Public Financial Management and 
Governance 
51.  After the adoption of a new regulatory framework of 2003-2004, the Government is 
implementing public financial management reforms as legislated. These efforts are part of a 
broader agenda to improve governance and enhance service delivery, with the ultimate goal of 
sustained economic growth and poverty alleviation. Progress has been achieved in the way 
public finances are managed and in increasing transparency and independent oversight. In 
particular,  progress  has  been  made  in  streamlining  the  budget  formulation  process  and 
documentation as articulated in new public financial management (PFM) laws. The Government 
is also beginning to address civil service reforms with a view to providing an enabling framework 
for more effective public institutions. These achievements provide a firm foundation for further 
progress,  but  significant  challenges  remain  across  the  public  financial  management  cycle 
including budget formulation, execution, and reporting and auditing. 
 
52.  Although the budget preparation process is not yet compatible with a medium-term fiscal 
perspective, progress is being made on this front. There has been some progress in recent 
years in terms of aligning policy priorities to allocations in the budget. The DPL-4/DPSP-3 also 
supported the introduction of a medium-term macro fiscal framework in the 2008 budget, with a 
system of forward estimates for two out-years. However, budget submissions continue to be 
annual and there is no framework to establish credible forward estimates that are reconciled 
with the projected resource envelope and other projections. To address this issue, the current 
program supports reforms to the budget preparation process by revising budget templates to 
give them a greater results orientation. Despite these efforts, the full development of a medium-
term expenditure framework (MTEF) can realistically only be achieved in the medium to long 
term.  
 
53.  With regard to the budget execution process, a number of challenges remain pertaining 
to cash management, processing, accounting and reporting of both revenue and expenditure 
transactions,  and  the  execution  of  capital  expenditures.  Progress  has  been  made  in  the 
development of a treasury single account (TSA) to strengthen cash management, but a number 
of accounts (e.g., salary accounts, revenue accounts) continue to hold idle cash balances and 
operational cash planning is at a very early stage of development. A chart of accounts broadly 
consistent with the Government Finance Statistics Manual (GFSM) 2001 was introduced in 
2005,  enabling  codification  of  expenditures  across  multiple  dimensions  and  stages  of  the 
expenditure management cycle, but some segments such as the activity and program codes 
need improvement. The Government also promulgated Government Accounting Standards in 
2005 that are being adhered to, and has made good progress in ensuring timely availability of 
annual financial statements to Parliament and to the public. Additional MOF regulations have 
put emphasis on ministers being responsible to record the budget allotment in their ministries; 
introduced new accounting subsystems at the treasury accounting system; and placed more 
emphasis on receivables, payables, and investment recording at the line ministries. However, 
there are problems in the application of the standards in the line ministries, and the systems and 
data environment for processing and recording of transactions is fragmented and not yet fully 
automated—undermining and the accuracy and reliability of financial reporting. This has led the 
external audit over the past years to issue a disclaimer audit opinion on the annual financial 
statements because of reliability and other issues. There are also problems in the execution of 
the capital budget, and procedural bottlenecks have caused expenditure patterns to remain

21
skewed toward the second half of the fiscal year. This has raised issues of quality of spending 
and project preparation and implementation. If not addressed expeditiously, these weaknesses 
in budget execution could potentially threaten the Government’s ability to maintain good fiscal 
discipline and expenditure management. 
 
54.  In  addition,  government-wide  civil  service  regulations  give  limited  flexibility  to  line 
agencies to attract, recruit, deploy, and retain staff with professional skills that match their 
increasingly  complex  operational  needs.  Centralized  controls  and  strict  guidelines  for 
organizational design applied government-wide create a rigid system that make adjustments of 
organizational  structures  difficult.  Taken  together,  these  regulations  impede  performance 
management and professionalism in public institutions. 
 
55.  The  DPL-5/DPSP-4  is  bolstering  critical  reform  measures  aimed  at  addressing  the 
challenges  identified.  Strategically  chosen,  the  DPSP-4/DPL-5  actions  support  the  broader 
governance agenda in Indonesia with actions focused on key aspects in budget preparation, 
execution, and civil service reforms. Specifically, the DPL-5 supports reforms to the budget 
preparation  process  with  a  view  to  instituting  more  results-oriented  budget  documents. 
Commensurate  with  the  significant  challenges  in  the  budget  execution  area,  the  program 
includes four reform actions to enhance budget execution, including further implementation of 
the TSA and automation of treasury operations, actions aimed at smoothing disbursement of 
capital  expenditures,  the  strengthening  of  accounting  capabilities  in  line  ministries,  and 
improving the institutional framework for procurement reforms. In addition, through the focus on 
civil  service  reforms,  the  DPL/DPSP  seeks  to  expand  this  reform  area  beyond  the  pilot 
spearheaded by MOF.  
 
a.  Trigger 8: Make further progress toward the establishment of a comprehensive TSA 
regime, including revenue accounts. Establish a counterpart team to implement the 
new automated treasury system, and begin mapping and reviewing of business 
processes to increase readiness for system rollout in 2009. Modernize 30 provincial 
treasury offices (KPPNs) (status: achieved) 
 
56.  Considerable progress has been made in implementing a TSA, as foreseen by the State 
Treasury Law, 2004. The rollout to the revenue accounts has commenced on a pilot basis after 
long delays brought on by protracted negotiations with Bank Indonesia and commercial banks 
on interest payment for government balances held at Bank Indonesia and remuneration of 
banking  services  by  the  Government.  The  Treasury  is  pilot  testing  the  daily  sweep  of 
government revenue deposits from collecting branches of the five largest commercial banks and 
post offices into the TSA with Bank Indonesia. The daily sweep is expected to be extended to all 
commercial bank branches starting January 2009. The daily sweep will be with respect to 
deposits made the previous day and not on the same day. This is because the commercial 
banks have agreed not to charge for this service provided the sweep is done the following day. 
This is a significant improvement over the current practice, established since 1989, of sweeping 
the revenue accounts twice a week. Concerning cash concentration of accounts held by line 
ministries, MOF has completed a census of all government accounts pursuant to the regulation 
on management of government bank accounts issued in 2007. This census identified 32,570 
such accounts. At the end of December 2007, 2,086 of these accounts were closed. Efforts are 
ongoing to determine further banks accounts of the remaining 30,484, which can be included in 
the TSA regime either directly or through a mechanism of daily sweeps into the TSA. 
 
57.  MOF is preparing for the implementation of an integrated financial management system 
to replace the multitude of financial data processing applications currently used by government

22  
institutions. The system, known by the acronym SPAN, will integrate and replace the multiple 
software applications within the treasury as well as those being implemented in the DG Budget 
to support the budget formulation process. Following a detailed internal review of the system, a 
new management and implementation structure for the automated treasury system was agreed 
upon, and a counterpart team for implementing the system has been established. The mapping 
and review of business processes has commenced.  The modernization of treasury offices has 
been completed in 33 out of 176 KPPNs, exceeding the trigger requirement. 
 
b.  Trigger 9: Enhance performance-based budgeting by initiating a review and revision 
of the existing program structure to increase accountability, revise the budget 
submission templates (for RKA-KL), draft accompanying budget preparation 
manuals, and draft key performance indicators for the Ministry of Finance (current 
status: achieved) 
 
58.  As part of the move toward program and performance-based budgeting, DG Budget in 
MOF has started to review and refine the Ministry/Institutional Budget and work plans (RKA-KL) 
and accompanying budget preparation manuals for six pilot ministries. This is with a view to 
simplifying the budget submission and to link it more closely to programs. Beside performance 
indicators, the templates also add narrative information on program strategies and objectives in 
order to provide a clearer link between program objectives and funding levels. The templates 
also contain columns for forward estimates of expenditures. The draft MTEF-performance-
based budgeting (PBB) budget preparation manuals are being finalized by DG Budget and 
Bappenas. The intention is to use the MTEF-PBB manual to guide ministries in their budget 
submissions pertaining to FY2010.13 
 
59.  In parallel, Bappenas, in coordination with MOF, is reviewing and revising the existing 
program structure. The new program structure will be embedded in the next 5-year plan, which 
will cover 2010–2014. The intention is to align programs to organizational structures to create 
an accountability framework. Key performance indicators for the Ministry of Finance have been 
drafted and are under review. 
 
c.  Trigger 10: All DIPAs are issued and teams assigned at the beginning of the 
fiscal year, by eliminating the annual surat keputusans requirement (for project 
managers) for multi-year projects and allowing for parallel processing of 
procurement. (current status: achieved) 
 
60.  DIPAs (spending warrants) for the 2008 budget were issued on 2 January 2008 and 
other actions to smoothen disbursement patterns are ongoing. DG Treasury is preparing a new 
regulation for accepting the names of key officials of satkers (project management units) listed 
in the DIPA as the legally authorized budget users of the satkers. This will obviate the need for 
issuing annual surat keputusans (decree letters) reappointing key satker officials. However, 
surat keputusans will be issued whenever there is a change in the incumbents. It is expected 
that the new regulation will become effective from FY2009. 
 
61.  The parallel initiation of procurement has been implemented in some line ministries, 
including the Ministry of Public Works.  While procurements can legally be initiated after the 
adoption of the state budget in October of the preceding fiscal year, this practice is not widely 
                                                 
 
13 The 2010 budget will be the first in the next 5-year planning period, which will outline the policy priorities of the 
incoming government after the general elections in 2009.

23
adopted because of a number of reasons. These include a lack of knowledge of this fact as well 
as  a  lack  of  operating  expenses  to  cover  procurement-related  costs,  including  posting  of 
advertisements and meetings of procurement committees. The main issue here appears to be 
anticipation of budget needs for starting the procurement process in the previous fiscal year by 
including a line item in the DIPA identifying pre-financing needs for the following year’s budget. 
The National Public Procurement Office (LKPP) has issued a circular to publicize this to line 
ministries, with guidance on how to initiate procurement steps prior to the start of the fiscal year. 
 
62.  The  detrimental  impact  of  slow  and  skewed  disbursements  of  capital  and  material 
expenditures has been widely recognized by policymakers and budget stakeholders at various 
levels.  The  Treasury  has  conducted  a  survey  of  the  impediments  to  the  disbursement  of 
budgetary funds through questionnaires. The results of the survey have been reviewed, and 
have formed the basis of an action plan, which has been drafted, to smooth out disbursements 
during the year.  
 
d.  Trigger 11: Complete a midterm review to assess the application of accounting 
standards and accounting procedure manuals by line ministries (current status: 
exceeded) 
 
63.  A midterm review was undertaken and revised accounting procedures for line ministries 
have been issued. MOF Regulation No. 171/PMK.05/2007 on Accounting System for Line 
Ministries was issued on 27 December 2007, replacing PMK 59/PMK.05/2005 on the Central 
Government Accounting System.  
 
64.  The revision was necessitated by significant problems in the application of the 2005 
standards in the line ministries. The annual financial statements of a number of line ministries 
receive a disclaimer audit opinion from the external auditor because of issues on completeness 
and reliability. The changes brought about by the new regulation include (i) an emphasis on line 
ministries being responsible for recording the budget allotment for their ministries; and (ii) an 
emphasis on recording receivables, payables, and investments by the line ministries with a 
requirement  that  these  should  be  recorded  and  reported  in  the  line  ministries’  financial 
statements.  These changes also represent an important step in moving towards full accrual 
accounting.  The changes should be reflected in the line ministries’ financial statements for 
2008, which should be issued in March 2009 
 
65.  The capacity constraints in the line ministries are being addressed through training of 
staff  on  these  changes,  and  accounting  issues  generally,  through  an  ambitious  training 
program.  The  target  is  to  train  over  7,000  accounting  staff  in  line  ministries.  So  far, 
3,185 persons have been trained. The goal is to train at least one staff in a satker by the end of 
FY2009. 
 
e.  Trigger 12: Make newly established LKPP operational by recruiting staff and 
allocating budget to cover operational costs and revise Presidential Decree No. 
80/2003 to, among others, accommodate a new set of standard bidding documents 
(current status: satisfactory) 
 
66.  The  last  year  has  seen  the  enactment  of  the  legal  framework  establishing  an 
independent Lembaga Kebijakan Pengadaan Barang/Jasa Pemerintah (LKPP) or the national 
public  procurement  office  reporting  directly  to  the  President.  The  development  of  the 
organization structure and staffing for the new LKPP is progressing well. In addition to the 
chairperson and an executive secretary, there will be four departments, each headed by an

24  
echelon  I  deputy  with  respective  responsibility  for  (i) strategy  and  policy  development, 
(ii) monitoring  evaluation  and  information  systems,  (iii) human  resources  development,  and 
(iv) legal affairs and settlement of objections. These six major positions have been filled, and the 
job descriptions for echelon II and III staff have been finalized and recruitment is ongoing. The 
necessary budget allocation for operational costs has been provided to LKPP. 
 
67.  Progress on streamlining the regulatory framework for public procurement is under way 
though perhaps not at the pace anticipated. Presidential Decree No. 80/2003 promotes the 
basic  principles  of  procurement:  transparency,  open  and  fair  competition,  economy,  and 
efficiency. It covers all areas of procurement that use public funds and contracting entities at all 
levels of government. However, the pace of Indonesia’s decentralization reforms has had an 
impact  on  public  sector  procurement  as  different  levels  of  government—from  ministers, 
governors, and even mayors—are able to issue their own decrees, regulations, and instructions. 
The plethora of regulations is often inconsistent with one another and many do not meet 
accepted international practice. Work on drafting a procurement law is in progress but finalizing 
the law and enacting it may require another 2–3 years as it has to go through Parliament plus 
the possible resistance by special interest groups. Meanwhile, LKPP is revising Presidential 
Decree 80/2003 to make it more user-friendly and update clauses where necessary. The first 
step  is  to  compile  and  consolidate  Presidential  Decree  80/2003  and  all  subsequent 
amendments into one document. This has been substantially achieved. The next step is to 
prepare  an  operational  manual  that  will  be  complemented  by  the  set  of  standard  bidding 
documents, which have been drafted with the help of ADB TA.14 Harmonizing Presidential 
Decree 80/2003 and the standard bidding documents with international good practice would 
improve procurement in Indonesia and could potentially increase the use of country systems in 
procurement under government projects financed by donors. 
 
f.  Trigger 13: Expand civil service reform pilot to five additional agencies in 2008. 
Update MOF organizational road map and implement next phase of the Ministry’s 
human resource management strategy (current status: satisfactory) 
 
68.  MOF is continuing to implement its human resource management strategy. New job 
descriptions  and  a  grading  system  were  introduced,  and  the  allocation  of  all  positions  to 
27 grades was finalized by the end of 2007. In conjunction, an extra allowance was introduced, 
determined by the new grading system. This represents the first step in an effort to improve 
performance, measure performance, and reduce corruption. Echelon I officials in MOF are now 
expected to resign from commissioner assignments in SOEs within their field of authority to 
reduce the potential for conflicts of interest. However, the other parts of this reform step have 
not yet been completed, and Key performance indicators have not yet been introduced, delaying 
performance-based  management.  Currently,  the  selection  process  for  recruitment  and 
promotion  is  being  transformed  into  a  process  based  on  announced  vacancies,  voluntary 
applications, and competitive selection based on merit; and an assessment center is being 
established to support the new policy. Simultaneously, the rotation policy (i.e., the policy under 
which civil servants in echelons II–IV are moved between offices, functions, and locations on 
average  once  every  third  year)  is  being  reviewed  to  support  career  development  and 
sustainability better. Development of a new intranet-based human resource information system 
has recently been initiated. The previously introduced road map development for MOF has been

25
replaced; the minister plans to introduce a law on MOF and a first draft academic paper for such 
a law has been prepared.  
 
69.  The five agencies involved in the civil service pilot are the Supreme Audit Agency (BPK), 
KPK, Ministry of State Apparatus Reform (MenPAN), MOF, and the Supreme Court. The rollout 
of civil service reform to agencies other than MOF is now done under the aegis of the National 
Committee for Bureaucracy Reform, by MenPAN. Three of the approved pilot agencies (MOF, 
BPK,  and  the  Supreme  Court)  have  all  received  extra  budget  allocation  to  cover  new 
allowances.  By  the  end  of  this  year,  BPK  and  the  Supreme  Court  should  have  made 
considerable progress in initiating reform.  KPK’s role is to monitor reform progress in the other 
institutions, as KPK is exempt from the civil service scheme and not in need of similar reforms. 
However, MenPAN has yet to implement similar reforms in addition to its activities to expand 
reforms to other institutions and/or regional governments. 
3.  Core Policy Area III: Improved Delivery of Public Services 
70.  Improving delivery of public services continues to be critical for Indonesia. Lagging 
human development indicators—such as the high maternal mortality rate, malnutrition rate, and 
low transition from primary school to secondary school—must be tackled by improving the 
quality of services. This goes beyond levels of public spending. It is about knowing what works 
and what does not. It is about institutionalizing program assessment and linking the findings with 
planning and budget allocations. It is about having a good system to target the marginalized 
groups. It is also about empowering local government, community, and service providers to 
deliver quality services. 
 
71.  Indonesia has recognized the importance of institutionalizing evaluation and assessment 
in the policy formulation and budgetary allocation processes. The intent is to promote a more 
adequate generation and systematic use of public performance information in decision making 
while  strengthening  effective  accountability,  within  the  Government,  service  providers,  and 
citizens. This is a complex and long-term objective, and can only happen by strengthening 
capacities to produce reliable and timely performance information, and through the introduction 
of  sound  institutional  arrangements  to  ensure  that  monitoring  and  evaluation  is  properly 
integrated into the management cycle. 
 
72.  Over the past few years, the Government has launched several large-scale programs to 
improve the access of marginalized groups to basic services. Improving targeting in these 
programs remains an ongoing challenge. Historically, household targeting systems in Indonesia 
have not been particularly strong. Not only do all programs have sizeable under-coverage and 
leakage errors, programs also tend to have different targeting systems. 
 
73.  After  decentralization,  about  one-third  of  total  public  expenditures  is  allocated  and 
implemented at the district level. Yet local governments have weak capacity to plan, budget, 
and execute spending of these funds, particularly in improving the delivery of public services. In 
recent years, this has been reflected in increased surpluses run by local governments. For more 
effective spending to take place, there needs to be a substantial improvement in the capacity of 
the local government and local service provider to plan, budget, and implement programs for 
better service delivery. 
 
74.  Indonesia has also had a long history of using communities to provide basic services to 
poor people through community-driven development projects. These have demonstrated that 
communities are well equipped to build and maintain village infrastructure, most often roads,

26  
bridges, water supply, irrigation systems, and markets. Community-based development also 
addresses in an integrated fashion the binding constraints to poverty reduction at the village 
level—whether these are village roads, water and sanitation systems, or other constraints to 
poverty  and  well-being.  With  the  launch  in  August  2006  of  the  National  Community 
Empowerment  Program  (PNPM),  the  various  community-driven  development  programs  are 
being consolidated and will be scaled up nationwide by the end of 2009. 
 
75.  Indonesia has identified education as one of the critical sectors with regard to improving 
the quality of life of its citizens and the attainment of its MDGs. In December 2005, with the 
passage of the Teacher Law, the Government launched a highly ambitious effort to upgrade the 
quality of its teachers. Under the new law, minimum service standards for education have been 
established with the help of ADB, and all teachers will have their basic salary doubled upon 
being certified as meeting the competency standards mandated by the law. Those in remote 
areas will be provided additional incentives, which will almost triple their basic salaries.  
 
a.  Trigger 14: Institutionalize a government system for program evaluation by 
appointing a Deputy for Performance Evaluation within Bappenas, with three 
directors responsible, respectively, for sectoral evaluation, regional evaluation, and 
systems and reporting of development performance (current status: achieved) 
 
76.  The Government has institutionalized systems for program evaluation by appointing a 
Deputy for Performance Evaluation (DPE) within Bappenas, with three directors focusing on 
sectoral  evaluation,  regional  evaluation,  and  on  systems  and  reporting  of  development 
performance. The DPE is currently developing a work plan and has been assisted in this task by 
a number of donors. A high priority is working together with MOF and other departments in 
Bappenas to prepare a new program structure more conducive to performance-based budgeting 
under the new medium-term development plan (2010–2015).  
 
b.  Trigger 15: Improve effectiveness in subnational spending by issuing guidelines for 
pro-poor budgeting and planning for local governments. (current status: achieved) 
 
77.  The Government has committed to making public expenditures more pro-poor. With the 
role of local governments in poverty reduction, economic development, and service delivery 
rising sharply in the years since the 2001 decentralization, public expenditures by subnational 
governments need to be made more pro-poor. To increase awareness of this need and build 
capacity at the local level, the Government with the assistance of ADB has issued guidelines for 
pro-poor budgeting and planning for local governments by producing a pro-poor planning and 
budgeting handbook.15 Bappenas launched the handbook in July 2008 and has disseminated it 
to 400 local governments, and uploaded it on its website. The plan is to follow up in 2009 with 
an extensive training program. 
 
c.  Trigger 16: Increase community block grant of PNPM to maximize employment and 
poverty impacts. (current status: achieved) 
 
78.  The block grant amount has been adjusted from about Rp1.5 billion on average in 2007 
to Rp1.8 billion in 2008. The Government is now planning for what increases will take place for 
2009. Studies have shown that the program is less effective in richer kecamatans (sub-districts), 
                                                 
 
15 ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance to the Republic of Indonesia for Pro-Poor Planning and Budgeting. Manila 
(TA 4762-INO, approved 1 September).

27
which already have more infrastructure, so the Government needs to think through the size of 
block grants for poorer areas versus richer ones. The Government has indicated its commitment 
to do so in the 2009 budget. 
 
d.  Trigger 17: Require teachers (other than head teachers) to be assigned a minimum 
of 24 teaching hours per week in order to receive either the professional allowance 
(for certified teachers) or the special area allowance (for teachers working in 
hardship areas), or a combination of both (current status: achieved) 
 
79.  The Ministry of National Education has issued a ministerial decree requiring all teachers 
to deliver 24 teaching hours per week in order to receive the professional allowance for certified 
teachers. In addition, teachers receiving the special area allowance are required to fulfill the 24 
teaching-hour requirement. Initial anecdotal evidence indicates that the policy is having its 
intended  effect  where  teachers  in  overstaffed  schools  are  requesting  to  be  moved  to 
understaffed schools. 
C.  Monitoring the Impact of DPSP-4 
80.  As part of the policy matrix for the DPL-1 (prior to ADB’s direct cofinancing involvement), 
outcome indicators and targets were introduced to highlight the expected key results of the 
support. These indicators were taken mainly from government planning documents. These 
indicators and targets have been adjusted as the program has evolved. They will form the basis 
for  evaluating  the  program,  and  will  be  complemented  by  other  indicators  such  as  the 
standardized public expenditure and financial accountability framework used to assess PFM. 
Such an evaluation was undertaken jointly by the Government, ADB, and the World Bank earlier 
this year for DPLs 1–4 and DPSP-1.16  
D.  Triggers for Future DPLs/DPSPs 
81.  The current DPL program is the fifth such operation in Indonesia, but is the first of a new 
three DPL series as proposed under the World Bank’s country partnership strategy for FY2009–
FY2012.  Indicative  triggers  for  the  remaining  two  DPL  series  have  been  developed  after 
detailed discussions between government counterparts and the three donors involved in the 
DPL/DPSP process, (Table 5). While triggers for DPL-6/DPSP-5 are fairly well defined, those for 
DPL-7/DPSP-6, which would be negotiated with the government that is in power following 
elections in 2009 are, of necessity, more tentative. The new program represents, in most 
respects, a continuation of the previous program in that it is structured around many of the same 
reform aims. Among the policy actions proposed are ones that are intended to further reduce 
uncertainty for investors, continue with the implementation of the NSW, further improve the 
results orientation of the budget process, further reduce tax compliance costs and enhance tax 
payer  services,  continue  to  improve  budget  and  cash  management  within  the  central 
government, continue the efforts to improve public procurement, and enhance the pro-poor 
impact of public service delivery.  At the request of the Government, facilitating trade integration 
and promoting export competitiveness, and strengthening management of state assets have 
been added as new reform aims of the program.

E.  Financing Plan 
82.  The Government has requested a loan of $200 million from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources for the DPSP-4. The DPSP-4 provides parallel cofinancing for the World Bank-
supported DPL-5, for which the Government has requested $750 million. The loan will have a 
15-year term, including a grace period of 3 years; an interest rate determined in accordance 
with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; a commitment charge 
of 0.15% per annum;17 conversion options that may be exercised in accordance with the draft 
Loan Agreement, the loan regulations, and ADB’s conversion guidelines; and such other terms 
and conditions as set forth in the draft program Loan Agreement. The Government has made its 
own independent decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility, and it has given 
an undertaking that this choice was not made on the basis of any advice from ADB. Responding 
favorably to the Government’s request will signal ADB’s relevance in an emerging, confident, 
and well-performing middle-income country. In addition, the Government intends to request 
$100 million from the Government of Japan for parallel cofinancing of the DPL-5. 
 
83.  Gross financing needs of the Government have increased from $11.5 billion in 2006 to 
$15.5 billion in 2007 and an estimated $17.5 billion in 2008. This reflects a higher fiscal deficit 
and high levels of domestic and foreign debt principal repayment. The Government has sought 
about $3.0 billion in program loan and budget support operations from development partners: 
ADB ($850 million); Agence Française de Développement ($200 million); Japan ($500 million); 
and the World Bank ($1.6 billion). For the proposed DPL-5, the World Bank envisages providing 
a $750 million program loan on International Bank for Reconstruction and Development terms. 
ADB’s proposed support is based on the strengths of the policy package, its development 
impact,  the  importance  of  the  sectors  covered,  and  the  investment  needs.  Besides,  the 
Government  will  incur  cash  outlays  in  excess  of  $200  million  to  implement  many  of  the 
institutional strengthening measures supported under the DPSP-4, such as fully operationalizing 
the NSW for clearance of merchandise and the proposed national procurement office. 
F.  Implementation Arrangements 
1.  Program Management 
84.  The  Coordinating  Ministry  of  Economic  Affairs  will  be  the  Executing  Agency, 
collaborating closely with MOF. Implementation of DPL-5/DPSP-4 actions is coordinated with a 
number of other ministries and agencies, including Bappenas, Ministry of Trade, Ministry of 
Cooperatives and SME, and Bank Indonesia.  
2.  Implementation Period 
85.  The program implementation period for the DPSP-4 is from January to December 2008.  
3.  Procurement and Disbursement Arrangements  
86.  The  program  loan  of  $200  million  will  be  released  in  a  single  tranche  upon  loan 
effectiveness.  The  loan  proceeds  will  be  used  to  finance  the  full  foreign  exchange  costs 
(excluding local duties and taxes) of items produced and procured in ADB member countries, 
excluding the items specified in the negative list of ineligible items (Appendix 8) and imports 
financed by other bilateral and multilateral sources. In accordance with ADB provisions for 
                                                 
 
17 ADB’s Board of Directors has discounted the commitment charge to 0.15%, and waived the front-end fee of 1.00% 
for loans approved from 1 July 2007 up to and including 30 June 2009.

31 
simplifying disbursement of program loans,18 the proceeds of the program loan will be disbursed 
to the Republic of Indonesia as the Borrower. No supporting import documentation will be 
required if during each year that loan proceeds are expected to be disbursed the value of 
Indonesia’s  total  imports  minus  imports  from  nonmember  countries,  ineligible  imports,  and 
imports financed under other official development assistance is equal to or greater than the 
amount of the loan expected to be disbursed during such year. The Government will certify its 
compliance with this formula with each withdrawal request. Otherwise, import documentation 
under existing procedures will be required.  
4.  Anticorruption  
87.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the Government. Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and 
transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or through its agents, any alleged 
corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to the Program. To support these 
efforts, relevant provisions of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy are included in the loan regulations 
and the bidding documents for the Program. In particular, all contracts financed by ADB in 
connection with the Program shall include provisions specifying the right of ADB to audit and 
examine the records and accounts of the Executing Agency and all contractors, suppliers, 
consultants, and other service providers as they relate to the Program. In addition, the DPSP-4 
has a core focus on improving governance and anticorruption. It promotes transparency in PFM. 
Noteworthy progress has been achieved through the TSA system and in the implementation of 
transparent accountability arrangements for central government investment funding (RDI) and 
regional development accounts, which will help the Government in its anticorruption efforts. The 
program’s focus on tax audit procedures, simplifying and/or eliminating unnecessary business 
licenses, and implementing good corporate governance in state-owned banks will also further 
the Government’s anticorruption agenda and improve the investment climate. 
 
88.  The Government places significant emphasis on strengthening internal control systems 
and  overall  PFM,  with  support  from  the  World  Bank  through  the  Government  Financial 
Management  and  Revenue  Administration  Project  and  from  ADB  through  the  State  Audit 
Reform  Sector  Development  Program. 19  Reforms  and  capacity  development  initiatives 
supported under both these programs have led to initial progress in strengthening PFM. 
5.  Accounting, Auditing, and Reporting 
89.  ADB retains the right to audit the use of loan proceeds and to verify the accuracy of the 
Government’s certification for the withdrawal applications. Prior to withdrawal, the Government 
will nominate a deposit account at Bank Indonesia to receive all loan proceeds. The account will 
be managed, operated, and liquidated in accordance with terms satisfactory to ADB.  
6.  Performance Monitoring, Evaluation, and Program Review 
90.  The Coordinating Ministry of Economic Affairs, MOF, and Bappenas will continuously 
monitor implementation of the DPL-related reforms and their impacts, in line with the overall 
program framework and outcome/output indicators agreed upon with the Government. The 
evaluation of the triggers is also done by the participating development partners based on 
frequent discussions with key government counterparts, and the collection of evidence in the 
form of key implementation decrees, circulars, etc.

V.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Expected Impacts 
91.  The key benefits expected from implementation of the Program are: 
 
(i)  progress in meeting the Government’s medium-term objectives through improved 
(a) investment climate, (b) public financial management and governance, and 
(c) service delivery to the poor; 
(ii)  raising the profile of key issues at the ministerial level, accelerating the timetable 
for  policy  actions  to  be  taken,  addressing  administrative  and  bureaucratic 
bottlenecks, and providing an impetus for decision makers to further coordinate 
across economic and line ministries; 
(iii)  sustained  ADB  engagement  in  policy  dialogue  with  the  Government  on  the 
direction  and  content  of,  and  strategies  for,  its  economic,  structural,  and 
institutional reform agenda (with the DPSP-4 providing for policy continuity and 
consistency in sectors where ADB has been actively involved); 
(iv)  aid harmonization and cofinancing by the key development partners (ADB, World 
Bank,  and  Government  of  Japan)  around  a  common  policy  framework  and 
dialogue, and the resulting endorsement of the Government’s macroeconomic 
management; and 
(v)  facilitation,  through  crosscutting  reforms,  of  sector-specific  reforms  in  areas 
where ADB is providing or planning support. 
 
92.  Institutional. Significant benefits stem from the engagement of Indonesia’s three main 
development  partners.  Participation  in  the  DPL  series  has  helped  in  overall  institutional 
coordination  among  the  partners  as  well  as  between  the  Government  and  the  partners. 
Provision  of  advisory  support  through  TA  has  also  been  significantly  streamlined  and 
coordinated to best meet the Government’s needs. The measures supported under the DPSP 
cluster will result in sustained institutional capacity in such key areas of policy formulation as 
fiscal policy, debt and treasury management, and public expenditure and financial management. 
 
93.  Social. The main contribution of support being leveraged through the DPSPs is in the 
form of improved public administration, sustaining effective public expenditure reorientation 
toward  productive  needs,  and  continuously  supporting  government  measures  to  align  its 
resources effectively with its medium-term objectives of economic growth and poverty reduction. 
By focusing on supporting strategic reforms aimed at improving public service delivery, the 
Program will have direct beneficial social impact. Appendix 8 presents a summary poverty 
reduction and social impact mitigation strategy. 
 
94.  Economic. The nature of the DPSP series limits the scope for quantitative economic 
analysis.  However,  qualitative  assessment  of  the  Program’s  outcomes  and  impacts  was 
assessed in terms of effect channels, stakeholder groups, and the expected time needed for 
effects to occur. In terms of effect channels, the Program will impact largely through lower 
business  transaction  costs,  improved  access  to  assets  (specifically  capital  for  SME),  and 
progressive improvements to both the quantity and quality of public services (including better 
targeting of such services to the poor). In terms of time, the net effect of lower business 
transaction  costs  from  regulatory  reform,  and  reduced  times  for  business  licensing,  VAT 
refunds, and import and export applications through the NSW are expected to be realized 
progressively over the medium term in the form of improved growth and poverty outcomes by 
indirectly encouraging competition and investment. The net effect of improved access to finance

33 
for SME is to reduce poverty indirectly through additional growth, to the extent that access to 
finance is a constraint to SME development. Initially, the main beneficiaries would be SME and 
larger enterprises, with benefits filtering to the wider population through increased employment 
generation. Indicators and the evidence base of effects of lower transaction costs, and improved 
access to financing of SME will be government agency surveys, competitiveness surveys, and 
cost-of-doing-business  surveys.  The  net  effect  of  reforms  to  the  budget  formulation  and 
execution  process—through  more  results-oriented  budget  documents,  improved  cash 
management, smoother disbursements of capital expenditures, and strengthened accounting 
capabilities in line ministries—is to improve budget allocations and operational efficiency with a 
possible increase in local service outlays, and reduction in corruption. This is likely to be 
enhanced  in  the  medium  to  longer  term,  with  the  progression  toward  medium-term  and 
performance budgeting, especially after full adoption of the MTEF approach in the next 5-year 
plan. Increases in the 2008 PNPM are expected to have a more immediate effect through 
increased  block  grant  transfers  for  subdistrict-led  community  development  projects,  while 
institutionalizing poverty program evaluations and assessments would lead to increased and 
better targeted programs in the near to medium term. Increasing the number of teaching hours 
by qualified teachers could have potential long-term impacts, to the extent that it increases 
educational outcomes—indicators and the evidence base are public expenditure reviews, civil 
service performance reviews, and benefit incidence surveys.  From a distribution point of view, 
the programs’ near-term impact on the poor will be realized mostly through the 2008 PNPM 
block grant increases, while improved service access and delivery for poorer groups will be 
realized over the medium to longer term. 
 
95.  Resettlement, Indigenous People, and Environment. Implementation of the DPSP-4 
measures will cause no direct or indirect involuntary resettlement, nor will it lead to any issues 
affecting  indigenous  peoples.  Based  on  desk  review,  the  measures  supported  under  the        
DPSP-4 are unlikely to have any adverse environmental impacts. 
B.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
96.  Implementation of the DPSP cluster is subject to the following risks: 
 
(i)  External vulnerabilities. With improvements in its macroeconomic indicators, 
Indonesia’s  resilience  to  external  shocks  has  increased.  Factors  limiting  the 
potential impacts of external shocks include diversity of exports, limited external 
debt exposure, and an adequate level of reserves. The banking sector is also 
now sufficiently strong to weather a moderate external shock. The maintenance 
of a financial sector safety net supported by the DPL/DPSP will help to improve 
the resilience of the banking sector. Nevertheless, risks remain high, especially 
during  a  period  of  global  financial  turmoil.  Indonesia  is  a  financially  open 
economy and there are significant foreign holdings, especially in the stock market 
and government bonds. Indonesia is thus vulnerable to sudden shifts in investor 
sentiment. If significant funds are pulled back because of liquidity demands in the 
US and elsewhere and/or increased emerging market risk aversion, this could 
lead to increased pressure on domestic interest and exchange rates. In addition, 
the Government has large gross financing needs over the next few years, and 
tighter credit markets and increased risk aversion could limit the Government’s 
ability to tap international financial markets. This could force the Government to 
cut budgetary outlays to maintain fiscal balance, with adverse consequences for 
infrastructure  and  social  expenditure.  Mitigating  these  risks  will  require  solid 
cooperation between Bank Indonesia and the economic ministries to reassure

34  
bondholders  that  their  investments  are  safe  (from  inflation  and  exchange 
movements) while crowding in private investment to the extent possible through 
the kinds of structural reforms supported by the DPL/DPSP. 
(ii)  Subsidies. As international oil prices decline, subsides also fall but they remain 
a key risk as commodity price reversions also remain possible. There remain 
significant subsidies on fuel and electricity in Indonesia, despite the increase in 
administered fuel prices in May 2008. Fixed fuel prices and the subsidies they 
create represent a threat to fiscal sustainability in the longer term (not to mention 
their  opportunity  cost, regressivity,  and  that  they  do  not  promote  efficiency). 
While a plan to move to market prices would be best, this is on hold until after the 
election in 2009. In the meantime, there are ongoing efforts to reduce subsidies 
in other ways. 
(iii)  Fiduciary constraints. Notwithstanding the improvements under way, there are 
continuing  concerns  regarding  utilization  of  public  resources.  The  overall 
fiduciary  assessments  undertaken  since  2001  (with  the  country  financial 
accountability  assessment)  have  indicated  considerable  improvements  in  the 
overall  fiduciary  environment  in  Indonesia.  Ongoing  programs  supported  by 
several  development  partners  provide  significant  TA  support  to  strengthen 
fiduciary  governance.  The  DPL/DPSP  focus  on  strengthening  budget 
preparation,  execution,  and  transparency  in  financial  management  will 
significantly enhance transparency. 
(iv)  The  2009  legislative  and  presidential  elections. Although the Government 
remains committed to sustaining its economic reform agenda despite the global 
economic slowdown and general elections next year, elections often reduce the 
time horizons of politicians, leading them to avoid new policy initiatives in the pre-
election period and shifting their focus to populist short-term measures. This 
could undermine the reform agenda contained in the DPSP-4. There is, however, 
also  the  possibility  of  a  countervailing  tendency  where  the  prospect  of 
approaching elections spurs political entrepreneurs into more clearly establishing 
reform credentials and recording clear accomplishments. 
(v)  Heightened  security  risks.  Alerts  stemming  from  sectarian  and  regional 
conflicts and terrorism could slow foreign direct investment and set back the 
recovering tourism industry. The Government and law enforcement authorities 
have  taken  a  range  of  measures  aimed  at  rebuilding  public  and  investor 
confidence. 
VI.  ASSURANCES 
97.  In  addition  to  the  standard  assurances,  the  Government  has  given  the  following 
assurances, which are incorporated in the legal documents:  
 
(i)  Counterpart funds will be used to finance the development needs as outlined 
under DPSP-4 implementation arrangements.  
(ii)  The policies and actions taken prior to the date of the DPSP-4 loan agreement, 
as described in the development policy letter (including the policy matrix), will 
continue to be in effect for the duration of ADB’s engagement in the DPL series, 
and subsequently.

35 
VII.  RECOMMENDATION 
98.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
$200,000,000 to the Republic of Indonesia for the Fourth Development Policy Support Program 
from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in accordance with ADB's 
London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; a term of 15 years, including a 
grace period of 3 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance 
with those set forth in the draft Loan Agreement presented to the Board. 
 
 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President

Appendix  3  45 
RESULTS ACHIEVED UNDER THE DEVELOPMENT POLICY LOAN/ 
DEVELOPMENT POLICY SUPPORT PROGRAM 
A.  Core Policy Area 1: Macroeconomic Stability 
 
1.  The  Development  Policy  Loan  (DPL)/Development  Policy  Support  Program  (DPSP) 
series  sought  to  improve  debt  management  and  fiscal  policy  management  by  reducing 
subsidies  to  the  nonpoor  and  making  revenue  administration  more  efficient  through  the 
expansion of modern tax officers. 
 
2.  Overall  macroeconomic  fundamentals  remain  sound  and  fiscal  consolidation  has 
improved  with  the  expansion  of  the  tax  base  and  improved  efficiency.  Economic  growth 
averaged a substantive 5.6% during 2004–2007, the debt–gross domestic product (GDP) ratio 
declined nearly 25 percentage points, budget deficits have declined, and high reserves provide 
the country with a comfortable liquidity cushion. Increasing non-oil and gas revenues as a 
percentage of GDP were supported by a prior DPL/DPSP action to expand modernization of tax 
offices and the tax base, including to medium and small taxpayers. These taxpayers are now 
responsible  for  the  largest  share  of  Indonesian  taxes.  Additional  reforms  to  improve  tax 
analysis, including the creation of a Tax Policy Office, are expected to generate improvements 
in revenue collection.  
 
3.  On the expenditure side, reductions in non-targeted fuel subsidies in 2005 allowed 
greater social spending but untargeted subsidies remain burdensome. In 2005, the Government 
raised fuel prices, resulting in the decline of fuel subsidies from 4% of GDP in 2004 to 2.7% in 
2007, freeing up $10 billion a year. This amount was rolled out into cash transfers targeted at 
the poor and also higher health and education expenditures. However, as oil prices continued to 
break record highs throughout 2008, fuel subsidies rose sharply, causing the Government to 
spend an additional Rp50 trillion (1.2% of GDP) in the first part of the year. In May 2008, the 
Government again increased fuel prices by almost 30% and accompanied this with a widely 
publicized and improved cash transfer program. This move, together with the recent reduction in 
oil prices, has brought down the projected energy subsidy in 2008 to 4.7% of GDP, which still 
surpasses both central government capital and social spending by 1.7% of GDP. 
 
4.  Rating  agencies  responded  favorably  to  Indonesia’s  lower  debt  ratio  and  reform 
packages. In a reflection of the country’s more sound economic footing, all three credit agencies 
have raised their credit ratings at least three notches since 2003. Standard and Poor’s upgraded 
Indonesia’s credit rating from CCC+ in 2003 to BB– by 2008; likewise in this period, Moody’s 
raised its ratings from B2 to Ba3; and Fitch raised its from B to BB. In supporting their ratings 
upgrades, the agencies cited debt reduction as the primary cause, as well as the Government’s 
commitment to broad-based reform, including changes to investment laws, customs and tax 
reforms, and fiscal reforms, specifically in treasury and budget—measures supported by the 
DPL/DPSP series.  
 
B.  Core Policy Area 2: Investment Climate 
 
5.  The DPL/DPSP series sought to improve the investment climate through several key 
entry areas, including regulatory reform, tax, custom and trade reform, financial sector stability, 
and improved access to finance by small and medium-sized enterprises. 
 
6.  Though  initially  slow  to  pick  up  momentum,  the  Government  has  made  strides  in 
improving the investment environment. Although full implementation of the investment packages

46    Appendix 3 
has yet to take place, initial signs are encouraging—investment rates have risen from below 
20% of GDP in 2003 to 25% in 2007. In 2006, the Government issued three economic policy 
packages  covering  investment  climate,  infrastructure,  and  financial  reform.  In  2007,  a 
comprehensive follow-up package was issued detailing 168 specific reform measures to be 
carried out. As a result, business perceptions have improved. A study of manufacturing firms in 
mid-2007  indicated  improvements  in  value-added  tax  (VAT)  refunds,  tax  filing  processes, 
informal payments, and faster import and custom clearance. Labor issues and infrastructure 
have now replaced consistency of regulation as the key constraint to doing business. Surveys of 
foreign investors also show that perceptions of Indonesia are improving. In Japan’s annual 
Japan Bank of International Cooperation survey of 600 Japanese multinational companies, 
Indonesia was ranked the eighth most promising country for overseas business.  
 
7.  Regulatory reforms supported by the DPL/DPSP process, particularly those relating to 
simplifying  and  eliminating  unnecessary  business  licenses  and  multiple  registration 
requirements, have led to more streamlined procedures supportive of the investment climate. 
According to Doing Business 2009, the time to set up a business has fallen significantly from 
168 days in 2003 to 105 days in 2007, and 76 days in 2008. Another key achievement was the 
passage of the Investment Law, which clarified previously arbitrary investment rules. The law 
focuses on equal treatment of foreign and domestic investment, removes the forced divestment 
and limited duration of foreign investment in the old law, lengthens the time horizon to hold land, 
liberalizes some immigration procedures, and allows for international arbitration.  
 
8.  Tax reform has addressed some of the key complaints from the business community. 
Reforms in tax administration have halved the time for VAT refunds; in addition, more than 
Rp10 trillion (roughly $1 billion) in outstanding VAT refunds have been settled. New procedures 
have been set in place to issue VAT refunds to export companies within set time frames. 
Standard operation procedures for a complaint management system have been issued. The 
DPL/DPSP has also supported the issuance of a decree on tax audit procedures that allows 
taxpayers to delay payment of tax assessments from disputed audits. However, this decree only 
becomes effective for disputes over 2008 assessments and forward, leaving those with current 
disputes under the old rule. 
 
9.  Significant progress on trade and customs reform has been made with pilot testing of 
Indonesia’s national single window (NSW) and paperless import clearance. Implementation of 
the NSW is one of the country’s most important trade facilitation initiatives. Under a single 
window, exporters and importers will no longer be required to apply individually to multiple 
agencies—significantly reducing the number of days it takes to export and import goods. A pilot 
project is under way in Jakarta’s main port and will be expanded to other ports in preparation for 
the establishment of an Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) single window. Other 
trade reforms sought by the DPL aimed to improve the technical capacity of the tariff team in 
setting and evaluating tariff changes and nontariff barriers imposed by line ministries. 
 
10.  The original objectives of the DPL/DPSP series were to strengthen the financial sector 
by reducing the role of state-owned banks and increasing the share of financial assets at 
nonbank financial institutions. The share of state-owned banks in the banking system (36% in 
June 2008) was a significant 10 percentage point decrease since 2003, indicating the increasing 
role  of  private  banks  in  the  sector.  Less  progress  was  made  on  the  nonbank  financial 
institutions—their  share  of  19.9%  of  total  financial  sector  assets  in  March  2008  was  little 
improved from the 17.4% share of 2005. However, other indicators point to a healthier financial 
system— profitability ratios such as net interest margin, return on assets, and return on equity 
remain strong. Nonperforming loans, particularly in state-owned banks have been substantially

Appendix  3  47 
reduced after peaking in 2005. In terms of diversification, small and medium-sized enterprises 
(SME) lending has been rising rapidly and now accounts for a majority share of the lending 
portfolio.  
 
11.  In  strengthening  the  stability  of  the  financial  sector,  the  DPL/DPSP  supported  the 
implementation of a sounder financial safety net. At the start of the DPL series, there was a 
need to reduce the economic distortion and potential moral hazard caused by the then existing 
blanket guarantee, which had been introduced during the Asian crisis to stem bank runs. To this 
effect, the DPL/DPSP series supported a number of reforms, including a deposit insurance 
scheme,  institutionalizing  Bank  Indonesia’s  role  as  lender  of  last  resort,  and  establishing 
institutional  processes  and  mechanisms  for  resolving  troubled  banks.  By  the  end  of  the        
DPL-4/DPSP-3,  coverage  on  deposits  was  reduced  from  a  blanket  guarantee  in  2003  to 
Rp100 million by 2007. Indonesia is one of the few countries in the world that has removed its 
blanket guarantee on schedule. 
 
C.  Core Policy Area 3: Public Financial Management and Governance 
 
12.  To  improve  the  efficiency,  transparency,  and  accountability  of  public  finances,  the 
DPL/DPSP  series  focused  on  three  key  areas  of  reform:  (i)  modernizing  public  financial 
management  systems,  (ii)  strengthening  institutional  reform  within  the  Ministry  of  Finance 
(MOF), and more recently (iii) civil service reform.  
 
13.  Changes in the legal and regulatory architecture for public financial management (PFM) 
are now largely complete and the focus is on implementing a modern PFM system. Before the 
start of the DPL/DPSP series, the Government’s financial operations were based on outdated 
laws (from 1925) that had been updated with a series of inadequate decrees. The previous PFM 
system  allowed  for  systematic  and  pervasive  corruption,  collusion,  and  nepotism  because 
assignments were unclear, transparency was low, and enforcement poor. Budget formulation 
was opaque and inefficient, making it difficult to quantify basic concepts of the budget. Budget 
execution was often delayed and monitoring arrangements were weak. Procurement processes 
were prone to corruption and collusion. Accounting and reporting were fragmented and not 
always reliable, and mandates of government audit bodies were not clearly defined. The DPL 
supported various regulatory measures needed to create the regulatory framework for a more 
modern PFM system, in the areas of budget preparation and execution.  
 
14.  A key achievement under the DPL/DPSP has been the implementation of the treasury 
single account (TSA) to improve cash management of public finances. At the start of the DPL 
series, more than 18,000 commercial bank accounts—and other accounts not even known to 
the Treasury—handled government funds. As an initial step, the DPL-1 supported addressing 
the regulatory deficiencies in the PFM system, including the passage of several laws defining 
the regulatory framework. Reorganization of MOF was also carried out to begin the process of 
establishing a TSA, and to clean up the cash management issues the Government faced. The 
DPL-2/DPSP-1  then  supported  the  implementing  regulations  underlining  these  laws  and 
adopted an implementation plan. The DPL-3/DPSP-2 pilot tested the TSA to have zero-balance 
accounts in over 50 provincial treasury offices (KPPNs). The DPL-4/DPSP-3 extended the TSA 
coverage to nearly full implementation on government expenditure accounts. Although there 
were some timing issues (e.g., training for local agencies to implement the TSA came after the 
requirement to do so), the push to meet the deadline of the DPL accelerated implementation of 
the  TSA.  Progress  on  covering  revenue  accounts  has  been  more  complicated,  but  has 
commenced.

48    Appendix 3 
15.  Budgeting  procedures  have  improved  but  execution  remains  problematic.  The 
DPL/DPSP has helped move forward reforms to reengineer business processes across the 
budget cycle. The national budget is now compatible with the international standard government 
financial statistics (GFS) classification. Fiscal reporting is more comprehensive and timely. 
Elements of a medium-term expenditure framework have been introduced, though not fully 
operational in the budget system. Whereas the planning and reporting side of the budget 
process has improved, executing the budget has remained weak, with about 50% of capital 
expenditure being spent in the last quarter.  
 
16.  Procurement reform, though slow to take off, now has the potential to exceed original 
expectations. The original trigger aimed only at strengthening the existing National Procurement 
Office. Instead, the Government has made it into an independent office responsible directly to 
the  President.  As  an  independent  agency  with  adequate  resources,  authority,  and  strong 
political backing, it will be in a stronger position to drive public procurement reform. However, 
because of the lag in strengthening the National Public Procurement Office (LKPP), there was a 
lack of progress on other procurement reforms, especially in developing a comprehensive 
national  public  sector  procurement  law.  This  law  is  needed  to  address  the  numerous 
inconsistencies resulting from decentralization reforms, which have enabled various government 
levels to issue their own procurement procedures. Other deficiencies of the system include slow 
progress in the passage of regulations, and the adoption of standard tools such as bidding 
documents and user manuals. 
 
17.  Initial steps to address civil service reform have been launched. Lack of administrative 
capacity  and  distorted  incentives  in  government  bureaucracy  have  constrained  policy 
implementation as well as delivery of public services. As an initial step to reform the civil 
service, the DPL/DPSP supported development of a comprehensive reform of the structure and 
remuneration framework for high-ranking state officials. A task force was set up to examine the 
entire compensation package with the goal of creating a more transparent, systematic, and 
coherent framework for pay and allowances based on a comprehensive job evaluation and pay 
grading. Building on this, MOF has developed a comprehensive civil service reform plan and 
action plan for itself, which is now being pilot-tested to other agencies.  
 
D.  Core Policy Area 4: Improved Delivery of Public Services 
 
18.  The groundwork for improving poverty targeting of basic services has been initiated. 
Prior to the 2005 fuel prices rise, Indonesia’s social protection system was characterized by 
emergency short-term safety net programs and price subsidies. The country’s three targeted 
programs accounted for less than 0.5% of GDP, compared to almost 4.0% of GDP for the 
untargeted fuel subsides, of which less than 0.2% of GDP went to the poorest quintile. As the 
fuel price hike made available more funds for social spending, the DPL supported building 
capacity to create a more evaluative institutional framework that would improve the targeting of 
these released funds. The 2005 fuel hike was accompanied by a new cash transfer program to 
help alleviate the impact on the poorest households—representing a substantial shift from the 
ineffective and inefficient general subsidy program. Evaluative assessments were conducted to 
improve  targeting  and  performance  of  the  cash  transfer  program,  and  the  lessons  were 
incorporated into the new cash transfer program that accompanied the May 2008 fuel price 
increase.  The  Government  has  undertaken  significant  steps  to  set  up  an  effective  and 
comprehensive monitoring and evaluation function, including the establishment of a unit to 
undertake performance evaluations, with the intent of having the findings used as an input to the 
Government’s planning and budgeting cycle.
